snippet: Q and A with François Payard, chef and owner of Payard Pâtissserie & Bistro.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that New York wasn’t always as dessert obsessed as it is now, with dessert restaurants, dessert trucks and a chocolate shop in every neighborhood. But when François Payard left the restaurant Lucas-Carton in Paris to become pastry chef at Le Bernardin in 1991, his creations were among the first to show New Yorkers that the last course deserved pride of place as great as the first. When he worked at Le Bernardin and later at Daniel his composed plates like pomme, pomme, pomme — apple sorbet on crisp apple sticks, with apple syrup and rings of baked apple chips — were highlights of the meal. Lines formed out the door for his fanciful pastries and fine croissants, brioche and chocolates when he opened Payard Pâtissserie & Bistro on the Upper East Side in 1997. Mr. Payard, 42, a third-generation pastry chef now has opened branches of the bistro in Brazil, Japan and Las Vegas and has written three books.
abstract: Q and A with François Payard, chef and owner of Payard Pâtissserie & Bistro.

snippet: Tweetmas lets Twitter users share their Christmas wish lists with their friends and the world.
lead_paragraph: This is part of a series of posts this week on happenings in the sprawling but always succinct world of Twitter.   Like Facebook and Apple with its iPhone, San Francisco-based Twitter has successfully captured the attention and energies of third-party developers, who have unleashed a wave of both practical and trivial applications that work with it.   We have chronicled a few this week, not because these particular Twitter tools are going to take over the world, but because they speak to the larger wave of innovation that is making the service much more than the sum of its parts.  So here's another one that caught our eye: Tweetmas. The app, developed by the London-based Crowdstorm, allows Twitter users to tell their followers what is on their wish lists for the holidays.   Like everything else with Twitter these days, amid the noisy clutter of 140-characters-or-less posts are some truly interesting and odd gems and trends. Among those using Tweetmas seriously, the Wii, iPod Touch and various coffee machines seem to be in vogue this year.   Then there are the more outlandish requests, such as:  A cure for my insomnia.  A maid to clean my room.  My girlfriend to stop ignoring me.  For Chocolate not to show on my hips.  I want this blond chubby Finnish girl wearing only those red Christmas laces.  To add to this poignant collection of holiday wishes, users simply post to Twitter with the command @tweetmas. The request will flow to their friends and appear on the Tweetmas site for all the world to see and puzzle over.  It is unclear, however, whether Santa has a Twitter account yet.
abstract: Tweetmas lets Twitter users share their Christmas wish lists with their friends and the world.

headline.main: All I Want for Tweetmas
headline.print_headline: All I Want for Tweetmas

lead_paragraph: The populist revolt against banking has begun. With trillions of dollars of taxpayers' funds being used to prop up lenders and investment banks, it was inevitable that banking executives would be forced to justify themselves to their new stakeholders. But if they thought an insurance fund manager with a lofty return-on-equity target was a tough customer, wait till they square off with John Q. Public. Bankers without articulate defenses for what they do - and why they are paid so handsomely - may find themselves out of a job.

snippet: Instead of looking for the next Jack Welch, Yahoo would do better to find its Tina Brown or Clay Felker.
lead_paragraph: Not surprisingly, there was a lot of talk on Tuesday about who should replace Jerry Yang as Yahoo's chief executive.   (Photo: ) Let me suggest that people are phrasing the question slightly wrong: Yahoo doesn't need a chief executive so much as an editor in chief. And I mean the sort of imperial editor who has a vision of how to create an environment that lures in both readers and advertisers, like Tina Brown, Clay Felker or Adam Moss.   In most conversations about the job, I hear people dismissing many names because this or that person "doesn't have enough management expertise." They say Yahoo is a big and complex business, and the ideal head should have run some sort of conglomerate.  That leads people to turn to names like Peter Chernin, the No. 2 executive at the News Corporation. That company, particularly the Hollywood parts in which Mr. Chernin specializes, is very much a portfolio business. You buy companies. You finance movies. You schedule TV shows. You bet on good managers, producers and directors. If you are right more than you are wrong -- as Mr. Chernin and his boss Rupert Murdoch have been -- the combination can make a lot of money.  I don't think that is the sort of boss Yahoo needs.   Indeed, part of the company's problems have come from thinking of its business as a portfolio of 100 loosely connected sites: Yahoo Finance, Yahoo Games, Yahoo Briefcase and so on. What's been lacking is a unified vision of what Yahoo stands for and how its parts fit together into a coherent experience.   That's what makes me think of those legendary editors who can inspire (and perhaps bully) people to coalesce around an idea. (If I was sticking with Hollywoodspeak, more a director than a studio boss.)  The very best Internet executives I know obsess about the experience their company provides. By experience, I don't just mean the user interface or features of a site. I mean the entire proposition of the company -- what it offers, how it makes money, how it talks about and supports its services.  Jeff Bezos is the longstanding champion of this approach to running an Internet company. Of the pioneers, I'd say Halsey Minor, the co-founder and first chief executive of CNet, had that editor-in-chief drive to put quality into so many parts of his company.   Apple is not exactly an Internet company, but Steve Jobs is also in the mold I'm talking about. He doesn't run Apple as a conglomerate. And he doesn't delegate anything important. It might not be fun to work there, but to consumers, there is no doubt what the company stands for.  Of chief executives at the current crop of Internet companies, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook most epitomizes the approach I think Yahoo needs. He might not be on anyone's list to be the next Jack Welch. But Mr. Zuckerberg has an incredibly clear idea of what Facebook is and isn't. Look at how he resisted all the pressure to copy MySpace, and how he even pulled back from the more chaotic aspects of Facebook's application platform. MySpace will do well, but Mr. Zuckerberg is building to his vision, and it resonates -- with consumers at least. (Advertisers are an open question.)  When you look at the names of people who are being bandied about for Yahoo's top spot, none really strike me as being that kind of leader. Most of them are people who have run non-Internet businesses or run online companies in the conglomerate style.   Even Jonathan Miller spent most of his time at AOL trying to concoct a strategy for how to replace the Internet access business. I don't think you can see his fingerprints much on how users interact with the service.   I can hear the objections to this concept. Whoever runs Yahoo will need to think about a broad range of issues, deal with Wall Street and financial matters and delegate product details to the staff.   My answer is that Steve Jobs doesn't do any of those things. Some of the other executives I mentioned do, but there isn't much to talk to Wall Street about if you don't have a business proposition that makes sense to customers.
abstract: Instead of looking for the next Jack Welch, Yahoo would do better to find its Tina Brown or Clay Felker.

headline.main: What Yahoo Really Needs Is an Editor in Chief
headline.print_headline: What Yahoo Really Needs Is an Editor in Chief

snippet: A front-page article and picture caption on Wednesday about the paralysis in New York State government as Gov. Eliot Spitzer deliberated whether to resign referred imprecisely to the address of his Manhattan apartment, where he spent the day with ...
lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Sunday about the Senate record of Barack Obama referred incorrectly in some copies to his position on a drawdown of troops from Iraq. After joining the Senate in 2005 Mr. Obama spoke in favor of a drawdown, including in a speech on Nov. 22 of that year. He did not propose a drawdown “only after he was running for president and polls showed voters favoring it.” (What he did do after becoming a candidate was to propose legislation calling for a drawdown.) (Go to Article)
abstract: A front-page article and picture caption on Wednesday about the paralysis in New York State government as Gov. Eliot Spitzer deliberated whether to resign referred imprecisely to the address of his Manhattan apartment, where he spent the day with family members and advisers. It is on Fifth Avenue between 79th and 80th Streets; it is not “at Fifth Avenue and 80th Street.”.

headline.main: Correction

headline.main: As Another Memoir Is Faked, Trust Suffers

snippet: The rumors were partly right. There is a $99 iPhone, and there are iPhones at Wal-Mart, but there are no $99 iPhones at Wal-Mart.
lead_paragraph: Well, the rumor mill was partly right. For weeks, there was speculation that Wal-Mart Stores would sell a $99 Apple iPhone.  (Photo: ) There really is a $99 iPhone, but it's not at Wal-Mart. And Wal-Mart really is selling an iPhone, but it's not $99.   The $99 iPhone is available only from AT&T, and the phone is -- as car dealers delicately put it -- pre-owned.  As long as the supply lasts, or until Dec. 31, AT&T is offering refurbished 8 GB iPhone 3Gs for $99 with a two-year contract (or to people who qualify for an upgrade). The 8 GB G3 usually sells new for $200. Don't rush to a store, though -- the refurbished phones can only be ordered online or by phone.   By refurbished, AT&T means someone else owned it first and returned it. The phone may show some wear, but it carries a 90-day warranty. New iPhones have a one-year warranty, according to an AT&T salesman I spoke to at the phone order center. AT&T representatives approached by phone and e-mail had not responded by the time this was posted.  Meanwhile, new iPhones are available at Wal-Mart, at a whopping discount of -- wait for it -- $2 off.  As I've said before, getting the iPhone into Wal-Mart doesn't seem like such big a deal. It may put it in front of some buyers who have only seen them on TV before, but I'm not sure that translates into tremendous sales.   Putting the iPhone in Wal-Mart is culturally significant, though. It shows how rapidly general acceptance of mobile computing is moving. In little more than a year, the elite smartphone with the most advanced technology has become conventional enough for the most mass-market of all retailers.
abstract: The rumors were partly right. There is a $99 iPhone, and there are iPhones at Wal-Mart, but there are no $99 iPhones at Wal-Mart.

headline.main: Where to Find a $99 iPhone
headline.print_headline: Where to Find a $99 iPhone

snippet: The author, driving through Virginia, encounters 100-proof moonshine . . . and Bolivian immigrants with a sauce to match it.
lead_paragraph: (The second in a series of essays leading up to the election by Bill Barich, as he undertakes a road trip inspired by John Steinbeck's "Travels With Charley.")  In Falls Church, Va., I did some accidental time-traveling one Sunday afternoon when I stopped at John Pistone's Italian Inn and revisited the optimistic 1950s after a heated passage through D.C. In the little horseshoe- shaped bar, a three-piece combo had just kicked into a killer version of "They Call the Wind Maria," and you could feel the ghost of Old Blue Eyes snapping his fingers to the beat while he asked for another double.  (Photo: Clifford Dewey and his friends. (Bill Barich))  Most of the regulars had left their youth behind long ago, but they still captured its cheerful, robust energies. Clifford Dewey, who often drives over from Maryland in a white Lincoln Town Car known as the Tuna Boat, was the life of the party. Dewey's an outrageous flirt, quick with a quip or a slap on the back. The gals seem to dote on him. Sinatra would have approved.   Dewey and I talked about the country's future. "Frightening," he said, and I prepared myself for the worst, but he meant frighteningly positive. The Depression, the big dip in the 1990s, we had weathered such economic turmoil before, and he believed we'd recover again. As a self-made man, Dewey trusted in human potential and the gift of opportunity.  He stamped his success story with the imprimatur Only in America. "I'm lucky," he began. "The Good Lord gave me a load of brains and the memory of an elephant. I had one of the highest IQs at my high school in Weymouth, Mass., and the lowest grades. Didn't even graduate. I started pumping gas at 16."  He joined the Navy to escape, grabbed a job as an auto mechanic on his return, moved up to selling parts, rose to the rank of general manager at 25, joined the giddy ride when his firm Car-Matic became a franchise, and cashed out for about a quarter-million in 1985, while also building a portfolio of investment properties.  Now Dewey's business card reads C.D. Dewey & Associates, International Financing, and it's no joke. He has fingers in many pies, including Dubai. He admitted he'd transferred some assets to an FDIC- insured bank, but he still had confidence in the dollar. He did feel bad for working people, though, who had only their paychecks to count on and no cushion of savings to soften the blow. They'd take the hardest hit.  Dewey urged me to try a slab of lasagna, but I had other plans. Falls Church is a polyglot place, with a vibrant mix of ethnic communities. I'd never eaten at a Bolivian restaurant before, so I voted with my feet for El Tutumaso, near my motel, where a delegation of Vietnamese dignitaries had attended a luncheon earlier that day.  I don't think Evo Morales was inside, but I'll give you 5-to-2 that a distant cousin sat before a plate of Pique Lo Macho or Silpancho. All the customers were Bolivian, as was the hip-hop on a flat screen TV, and family groups conversed quietly, while the kids dashed about. I heard no uproar of excited money, no bellow of power and circumstance. There was only the sweet mood of surcease that a Sunday evening deserves.  The Charque I ordered tested me, though. Shredded beef, some pozole-like corn kernels, boiled potatoes, hard-boiled eggs, a hot sauce I applied in heaping doses to prove to the server, who warned me to be careful, that I could handle it — well, I could not. I failed to win my Bolivian merit badge.  Farther down the road, as I veered from my original intention to stick to U.S. 50, a goal no true vagabond could ever fulfill, I reached Culpeper, Va., where the immigration I'd witnessed in Falls Church is a contentious issue, literally front-page news. The paper's other lead story addressed the question of whether or not citizens should be allowed to bear arms at public meetings.   Culpeper's recent history would be familiar to many other small American cities. It hit the skids about 20 years ago, and the downtown fell to drugs and prostitutes, but a concerted civic effort turned the tide, and now central Culpeper has a clean, smart, mildly trendy look that pleases both the locals and tourists.  (Photo: Ed Perryman. (Bill Barich)) On the other hand, its suburban fringe has a massive rate of foreclosure, the result of a brief construction boom before the recent collapse. It brought an army of eager Mexican laborers into the county, but now that the work has dried up, some folks in Culpeper would like the Mexicans to disappear, although Ed Perryman doesn't share that view. We bumped into each other on Main Street after an aggressive or stoned driver almost ran us down.  "I'm going to be 80 pretty soon, in November," Perryman confided. "I've been retired since '91, used to work for a paper company. I keep busy making furniture for those who ask. I started farm work as a boy for a dime a day — 'course you could buy two pounds of beans for a quarter back then. The future looks pretty bad to me. Too much modern stuff. Too many white collars, and not enough people working.  "The thing about the Mexicans is, they're good people. They treat me good and I treat them good. What I don't like is too much government. If I want to build a pigpen, I've got to get a permit now. I'm a Baptist and never been in trouble in my life. Never been in a jailhouse, either. 'Course, I had a couple of speeding tickets, but everybody gets a few of those."  Permits weren't a problem in Culpeper in the old days. If you wanted to shoot a varmint, the sheriff gave you one. He still will, but only if you have at least an acre of land. The clustered suburbs are a danger zone, in case a bullet goes astray. According to Beth Burns, who runs the tourist office, the controversy even attracted the attention of some "gun fanatics"' from northern Virginia. Adepts of the Second Amendment, they showed up for meetings packing heat, and the matter was referred to a committee.   Virginia is a so-called "battleground state," as the Beltway pundits put it, and Beth says that the downtown area divides about evenly in terms of preference. Along East Street it's all McCain, and in her neighborhood it's all Obama, whose troops stole a march on the Republicans and opened a Main Street office a month before the GOP followed suit. Some think Hillary's strong showing in the primary provided the encouragement.  A tip from Beth led me to Belmont Farm on Cedar Run Road, where the only legal distiller of moonshine in Virginia operates. Corn grew along the dirt road to the farm, the same corn Chuck Miller grinds for his Kopper Kettle Whiskey, a companion brand to his Virginia Lightning, a 100-proof brew guaranteed to curl your toes. I found Chuck toasting apple wood chunks over an open fire. Later he'd drop them into a mesh bag and sink them into a vat of whiskey to add some flavor.   Chuck and his wife, Jeanette, settled on their expansive spread in 1975. Initially, he wanted to grow wine grapes, but his land flooded and the grapes did poorly, so he decided to go back to his roots. His grandfather was a bootlegger, after all, who never once got caught by the law, only by the IRS, and was forced to sell 11 houses to pay the bill for his back taxes.  Chuck is a terrific scavenger. "You gotta be if you expect to make it in this old world," he said, as country music played from a couple of strategically placed radios. He takes particular pride in his pot still, manufactured in New York in 1933 when Prohibition ended. He also owns a Filabelmatic machine for slapping on labels, a relic from 1945. His whiskey barrels were Virginia oak, deliberately charred inside for yet more flavor.  The law forbids Chuck from dispensing any liquor for tasting, but I bought a bottle of Kopper Kettle on faith, and my faith was rewarded. I wondered what Chuck thought about the coming election.  "Well, there's a lot that's the same about the candidates," he ventured. One, they both want to get out of Iraq. Two, they both want to fix Afghanistan. But McCain supports free enterprise, and that's good for business. Obama just wants to lower taxes."  Jeanette joined the debate, and she sounded fretful. "It's so emotional this year. Chuck and his brothers just argue."  Steinbeck, a Democrat, had similar difficulties in 1960. "I arrived in Monterey and the fight began. My sisters are still Republicans…I can discuss politics coldly and analytically with strangers. That was not possible with my sisters." I understood his point.  "Obama's a socialist," Chuck continued, "and I'm not in favor of killing little babies." (Photo: Williams Apple Orchard. (Bill Barich))  I thanked my hosts for the tour, and took Route 522 toward Shenandoah National Park. The Indian Summer sun was hot, the air smelled of freshly mown grass, and Williams Apple Orchard completed my little slice of paradise. I passed up a bushel of Yorks for a half peck of Virginia Golds, a cross between the Albermarle Pippin and the Golden Delicious. Liz, who helps to manage the orchard, filled my bag right to the top and swore the apples would still be crisp when I got to San Francisco.
abstract: The author, driving through Virginia, encounters 100-proof moonshine . . . and Bolivian immigrants with a sauce to match it.

headline.main: In Virginia, Hot Sauce and Moonshine
headline.print_headline: In Virginia, Hot Sauce and Moonshine

lead_paragraph: The publisher of a children’s book based on the fabricated love story of Herman Rosenblat, the Holocaust survivor who said he first met his wife when he was imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp, has canceled pending reprints of the book and will refund the price of any returned books.In a statement released late Monday, Minneapolis-based Lerner Publishing said it was “shocked and disappointed to learn that the widely publicized Holocaust love story of Herman and Roma Rosenblat, which inspired the children’s picture book ‘Angel Girl,’ is not entirely true.”

lead_paragraph: How much impact is the promise of the iPhone having on venture capital?

headline.main: Free the Phone, and Venture Capital Will Follow

snippet: The trend toward allowing consumers to use a wider variety of applications on their cellphones is leading to greater investment in such applications, according to a research firm.
lead_paragraph: How much impact is the promise of the iPhone having on venture capital?  Plenty, according to Rutberg & Co., a San Francisco-based technology research firm. Venture capital investment in mobile consumer applications jumped 90 percent in the first half of 2008, to $383 million, from $202 million in the second half of 2007.  By contrast, venture investment in cell towers, networking equipment and antennas dropped $456 million to $383 million in that period. And investments in niche or regional companies seeking to compete with the likes of AT&T, Verizon and Sprint is down too, to $141 million in the first half of this year from $463 million in the second half of 2007.  There are several reasons for the shift, said Rajeev Chand, a Rutberg analyst who helped compile the data. The largest mobile virtual network operators, or MVNO's, proved to be failures last year so many investors are staying away. (One of those was Disney Mobile, which was shuttered not long after ESPN abandoned its MVNO.) Secondly, he said, as AT&T and Verizon Wireless get even bigger, there is little incentive for venture capitalists to invest in competitors.  But an equally important reason for the shift in financing is the iPhone halo effect. Mr. Chand suggested that the control wireless carriers once had over what developers could offer consumers on mobile phones is slipping, making it more desirable for venture capitalists to invest in emerging consumer applications. In the iPhone's case, AT&T does not have a say in what applications Apple makes available to consumers, a trend analysts say will be followed by other device makers.  "The real question is what, if any, new properties come out of mobile," Mr. Chand said. "If we see plenty of those, the money will follow."
abstract: The trend toward allowing consumers to use a wider variety of applications on their cellphones is leading to greater investment in such applications, according to a research firm.

snippet: AT&T added two new international data plans for U.S.-based iPhone users roaming overseas. One of the plans costs as much as the Apple iPhone handset.
lead_paragraph: AT&T hasn't had a lot of good news lately. The new Apple iPhone 3G has caused headaches among buyers who are complaining about dropped calls and poor network coverage. The blogosphere is atwitter, too, wondering whether the iPhone is worth the hefty price.  Now AT&T, exclusive United States carrier for the iPhone, has two new ways for consumers to part with their hard-earned cash. On Tuesday, it announced two additional international data plans for the iPhone, one of which costs as much as the phone itself.   Heavy data users have two new options: pay $120 a month for 100 megabytes of international data use or $200 for 200 megabytes. Previously, AT&T announced a 20-megabyte plan for $25 and 50-megabyte plan for $60 plan. A word of caution: Those fees are in addition to what customers already pay to use the phone in the United States.   It's enough to make even ardent iPhone fans suffer sticker shock. But AT&T, like its competitors Verizon Wireless and Sprint Nextel, want users to get hooked on surfing the Web or downloading maps wherever they are because customers pay more for those plans than regular voice plans.  AT&T's rationale for the fees is that it costs iPhone users traveling abroad an eye-popping $40 to download a three-minute video from YouTube (using two megabytes of data) without one of their plans.   AT&T says customers can cancel whenever they want, but there are caveats. If you are overseas for only a week, you still have to pay for the whole month -- an AT&T spokesman said the company doesn't prorate the fees. And if you forget to cancel the plan after you get home, you will continue to be charged. AT&T won't let you specify ahead of time when you want the international plan to end.
abstract: AT&T added two new international data plans for U.S.-based iPhone users roaming overseas. One of the plans costs as much as the Apple iPhone handset.

headline.main: AT&T Introduces New Data Plans for iPhone Users Roaming Abroad
headline.print_headline: AT&T Introduces New Data Plans for iPhone Users Roaming Abroad

lead_paragraph: Paris — U.S. stocks gained for a fourth day Wednesday as investors snapped up technology shares trading near their cheapest level on record, overpowering earlier declines spurred by economic data depicting a deepening recession. Apple and Microsoft led computer companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index higher as the group traded for 12.8 times reported earnings. General Motors and Ford Motor, which will make their case for federal bailout funds after the Thanksgiving holiday, rallied more than 14 percent. The S&P 500 climbed 0.6 percent to 863.54 after earlier sliding as much as 1.9 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 58.3 points, or 0.7 percent, to 8,537.77. The Nasdaq Composite index added 2.1 percent to 1,495.89. The S&P 500 Tuesday climbed for a third day after the deepening recession prompted the Federal Reserve to commit as much as $800 billion to help resuscitate lending to homeowners, consumers and businesses. The index has tumbled 41 percent this year as credit-related losses and writedowns at financial companies worldwide approached $1 trillion, threatening global economic growth. Benchmark indexes also erased an earlier tumble after President-elect Barack Obama picked former Federal Reserve chief Paul Volcker to head an economic advisory board and said he will implement a plan to bolster growth on "day one." Earlier declines in the stock market came after government reports showed orders for durable goods shrank 6.2 percent, twice as much as forecast, and consumer spending declined the most since 2001. "The reality is 2009 is pretty much set up to be a rough year economically," said Hayes Miller, head of the North American investment team at Baring Asset Management.

snippet: A children's book based on the fabricated story of Herman Rosenblat, who said he first met his wife when he was imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp, has been canceled by its publisher.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: The children's book "Angel Girl," based on the fabricated story of Herman Rosenblat, has been canceled by its publisher. (Lerner Publishing)) The publisher of a children's book based on the fabricated love story of Herman Rosenblat, the Holocaust survivor who said he first met his wife when he was imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp, has canceled pending reprints of the book and will refund the price of any returned books. In a statement released late Monday, Minneapolis-based Lerner Publishing said it was "shocked and disappointed to learn that the widely publicized Holocaust love story of Herman and Roma Rosenblat, which inspired the children's picture book 'Angel Girl,' is not entirely true."  "Angel Girl," by Laurie Friedman, was published in September with illustrations by Ofra Omit. It told the story of how Mr. Rosenblat met his future wife when he was a prisoner and she was disguised as a Christian farm girl and tossed him apples and other food over the fence of the Schlieben camp in Germany. In the story, the protagonist meets the girl again years later on a blind date in New York.   Mr. and Mrs. Rosenblat had told versions of this story on Oprah Winfrey's show, as well in newspaper and magazine stories. Ms. Friedman had spent several days interviewing the couple. "Based on Mr. Rosenblat's consistency and level of detail, and the long-running coverage of this story in the media, Ms. Friedman and Lerner Publishing Group had trusted the accuracy of this story," the publishers' statement said.   In the statement, Adam Lerner, president and publisher of Lerner, said: "While this tragic event in world history needs to be taught to children, it is imperative that it is done so in a factual way that doesn't sacrifice veracity for emotional impact. We have been misled by the Rosenblats, who gave us and our author what we believed to be an authentic and moving account of their lives."
abstract: A children's book based on the fabricated story of Herman Rosenblat, who said he first met his wife when he was imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp, has been canceled by its publisher.

snippet: Luis Lara Malvacías’s “Reason Without Meaning” is being performed at The Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Luis Lara Malvacías, a choreographer, dancer and visual artist, has clearly spent a lot of time thinking about the set for his new dance, “Reason Without Meaning.” His installation even spills into the audience at the Kitchen, where the back of every other chair is covered with a slice of bubble wrap. A black piece of cardboard with a message reading “X caution” is placed on the same seats, along with an object wrapped in more bubble packing to resemble a candied apple. Or, judging by the events that follow, a grenade.
abstract: Luis Lara Malvacías’s “Reason Without Meaning” is being performed at The Kitchen.

headline.main: A Look at War, That Zero-Sum Game
headline.print_headline: A Look at War, That Zero-Sum Game

To me, the flavor of the celery look-alike was so closely akin to the candy Good & Plenty that it quickly became a special treat.

snippet: The flutist and composer Guo Yue’s first book for children is about a musical child in Mao’s China.
lead_paragraph: A flutist and composer, Guo Yue has subtitled LITTLE LEAP FORWARD, his first book for children, A Boy in Beijing (Barefoot Books, $16.99; ages 8 to 14). But an equally apt subtitle might have been “A Portrait of the Musician as a Young Boy,” for one of the many pleasures of this moving story — whose co-author, Clare Farrow, is Yue’s wife — is its depiction of how a musical child experiences the world as a symphony of sounds. The warm wash of color and the textured detail in Helen Cann’s illustrations reinforce the novel’s pastiche of folk tale, parable and realism.
abstract: The flutist and composer Guo Yue’s first book for children is about a musical child in Mao’s China.

headline.main: A Reed Grows in Beijing

snippet: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.
lead_paragraph: Why does Philips–the Dutch electronics and appliance giant–seem to have such difficulty gaining traction in the United States? In Europe, it’s a dominant brand, but its sales in the United States have often prompted expressions of unhappiness from its corporate parent. After pioneering plasma TV in American almost ten years ago, the company, which now concentrates on LCD displays, seems like an also-ran in the TV business in this country.
abstract: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.

headline.main: A New Approach for Philips

snippet: Sweet Mama’s Good Kitchen is as retro and charming as the pint-size model of a red ’57 Chevy that sits on its shingled roof.
lead_paragraph: Sweet Mama’s Good Kitchen is as retro and charming as the pint-size model of a red ’57 Chevy that sits on its shingled roof. Inside the white clapboard house on the corner of Alsace Place and Route 25A in Northport, yellow-checkered tablecloths, wainscoting and vinyl-and-chrome chairs recreate the cheery look of a small-town 1950s luncheonette. Ketchup bottles and maple syrup dispensers sit on every table.
abstract: Sweet Mama’s Good Kitchen is as retro and charming as the pint-size model of a red ’57 Chevy that sits on its shingled roof.

headline.main: You’ll Remember Mama’s
headline.print_headline: You’ll Remember Mama’s

snippet: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.
lead_paragraph: Why does Philips–the Dutch electronics and appliance giant–seem to have such difficulty gaining traction in the United States? In Europe, it’s a dominant brand, but its sales in the United States have often prompted expressions of unhappiness from its corporate parent. After pioneering plasma TV in American almost ten years ago, the company, which now concentrates on LCD displays, seems like an also-ran in the TV business in this country.
abstract: Philips, the dominant electronics maker in Europe, has never had the same kind of success in the United States. But it keeps trying, this time with a lighted bezel for its TV sets.

headline.main: A New Approach for Philips

snippet: On Thursday, the company unveiled the Mini 9, a $349 portable computer that weighs 2.28 pounds, has an 8.9-inch screen and is tailored for Internet-centric tasks.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: ) As expected, Dell has joined the netbook party. On Thursday, the company unveiled the Mini 9, a $349 portable computer that weighs 2.28 pounds, has an 8.9-inch screen and is tailored for Internet-centric tasks, like surfing, chatting, uploading photos, blogging, watching videos and listening to music.  Wait, aren't those the main tasks many people use their computer for? Yep, and that's why the industry should be increasingly nervous about this new category of low-cost computers.  As we've written about earlier, the emergence of a category of Internet-centric computing devices challenges the already reed-thin profit margins of the PC industry. It inches the industry away from its long-standing goal –- and economic model -- of building ever-more powerful computers.  It also challenges some of the biggest American PC companies, given that the pioneers in the category are lesser-known overseas manufacturers, like Asus, the maker of the Eee PC. And it challenges some of the suppliers, like Microsoft, that are tailored for a world of powerful computers, not basic ones that function chiefly as way stations to connect consumers to the cloud.   Indeed, the base model of Dell's new machine includes a "mini" operating system made by Ubuntu (a $399 model has Windows XP Home). The machine does, however, use an Intel Atom chip, whereas some of the other low-cost PCs are using processors made by other manufacturers, challenging Intel's dominance of the PC platform.  The Mini 9 comes in two colors (which Dell ostentatiously, though perhaps accurately, refers to as "Obsidian Black" and "Alpine White," showing that the PC makers are bringing their stylistic efforts to this low-price category). One wonders whether this new category will, over the long-term, challenge the PC makers in their efforts to reproduce their favorite color: U.S. Dollar Green.   One last bit: Dell's announcement about the new Mini 9 is a kind of polar opposite of an Apple product launch; in other words, the Mini 9 was a terribly kept secret. Michael Dell, the company's chief executive, was carrying around a prototype earlier this year, stoking speculation about such a product.
abstract: On Thursday, the company unveiled the Mini 9, a $349 portable computer that weighs 2.28 pounds, has an 8.9-inch screen and is tailored for Internet-centric tasks.

headline.main: Dell, a Bit Late, Gets Small
headline.print_headline: Dell, a Bit Late, Gets Small

snippet: Open-air cafes, historic homes and rolling hills give the charming town of Frederick, Md., a cozy atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: DRIVING out of Baltimore, my home, I felt like the urban sprawl of shopping centers and rows of blighted homes would never end. But less than an hour west of the city, outside Frederick, Md., strip malls gave way to strips of giant trees turning autumn crimson, and the vista opened into broad plains, rolling hills and the occasional barn. By the time I crossed Frederick’s outskirts, where I saw brick colonial-looking homes and signs for local farms, I felt I’d arrived in a place far from the megacities of the Eastern Seaboard  like the frontier, but just off Interstate 70.
abstract: Open-air cafes, historic homes and rolling hills give the charming town of Frederick, Md., a cozy atmosphere.

headline.main: Echoes of Yesteryear Not Far From Baltimore
headline.print_headline: Echoes of Yesteryear Not Far From Baltimore

Wait, aren't those the main tasks many people use their computer for? Yep, and that's why the industry should be increasingly nervous about this new category of low-cost computers.  As we've written about earlier, the emergence of a category of Internet-centric computing devices challenges the already reed-thin profit margins of the PC industry. It inches the industry away from its long-standing goal –- and economic model -- of building ever-more powerful computers.  It also challenges some of the biggest American PC companies, given that the pioneers in the category are lesser-known overseas manufacturers, like Asus, the maker of the Eee PC. And it challenges some of the suppliers, like Microsoft, that are tailored for a world of powerful computers, not basic ones that function chiefly as way stations to connect consumers to the cloud.   Indeed, the base model of Dell's new machine includes a "mini" operating system made by Ubuntu (a $399 model has Windows XP Home). The machine does, however, use an Intel Atom chip, whereas some of the other low-cost PCs are using processors made by other manufacturers, challenging Intel's dominance of the PC platform.  The Mini 9 comes in two colors (which Dell ostentatiously, though perhaps accurately, refers to as "Obsidian Black" and "Alpine White," showing that the PC makers are bringing their stylistic efforts to this low-price category). One wonders whether this new category will, over the long-term, challenge the PC makers in their efforts to reproduce their favorite color: U.S. Dollar Green.   One last bit: Dell's announcement about the new Mini 9 is a kind of polar opposite of an Apple product launch; in other words, the Mini 9 was a terribly kept secret. Michael Dell, the company's chief executive, was carrying around a prototype earlier this year, stoking speculation about such a product.
abstract: On Thursday, the company unveiled the Mini 9, a $349 portable computer that weighs 2.28 pounds, has an 8.9-inch screen and is tailored for Internet-centric tasks.

headline.main: Dell, a Bit Late, Gets Small
headline.print_headline: Dell, a Bit Late, Gets Small

snippet: Open-air cafes, historic homes and rolling hills give the charming town of Frederick, Md., a cozy atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: DRIVING out of Baltimore, my home, I felt like the urban sprawl of shopping centers and rows of blighted homes would never end. But less than an hour west of the city, outside Frederick, Md., strip malls gave way to strips of giant trees turning autumn crimson, and the vista opened into broad plains, rolling hills and the occasional barn. By the time I crossed Frederick’s outskirts, where I saw brick colonial-looking homes and signs for local farms, I felt I’d arrived in a place far from the megacities of the Eastern Seaboard  like the frontier, but just off Interstate 70.
abstract: Open-air cafes, historic homes and rolling hills give the charming town of Frederick, Md., a cozy atmosphere.

snippet: City Room reflects back at 2008, a year of collapses, resignations and waterfalls.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Robert F. Kennedy, who died in 1968, and Caroline Kennedy, who wants to be appointed to the Senate, were in the news this year. (Photos: left, Charlie Tasnadi/Associated Press; right, Don Heupel/Associated Press)) City Room returns to its annual tradition (which we can call annual because we  did it last year) of reviewing the year in highs and lows.   Least controversial Kennedy-related state action: The renaming of the Triborough Bridge in honor of Robert F. Kennedy. Most controversial Kennedy-related state action: Gov. David A. Paterson's consideration of Caroline Kennedy for the Senate seat being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton.  Most aggressive use of rent-stabilized apartment building by a landlord: The Economakis family's plan to push out tenants and convert their building's 15 rent-stabilized apartments into an 11,000-square-foot home for themselves. Most aggressive use of rent-stabilized apartments by a tenant: Representative Charles B. Rangel's use of four rent-stabilized apartments, including three adjacent units on the 16th floor, at Lenox Terrace in Harlem.  (Photo: The Mayflower Hotel. (Photo: Larry Downing/Reuters))   Politician whose career ended with an encounter in Room 871 in the Mayflower Hotel: Eliot Spitzer, who resigned as governor of New York  in March after reports that he had been involved with prostitutes. Musician whose career began with an encounter in Room 871 in the Mayflower Hotel: Ashley Alexandra Dupré, whose songs "Move Ya Body" and "What We Want" were downloaded by hundreds of thousands of people after her name emerged in the Spitzer scandal.  Large-scale predatory check-cashing practice: Tax-refund-anticipation loans, which the state claimed were aimed at low-income black and Hispanic families and military families in violation of state antidiscrimination laws. Small-scale predatory check-cashing practice:  The wheeling of a corpse to a paycheck outlet to claim a Social Security payment, in the case of the late Virgilio Cintron and his friends.  Modest but effective policy change for the city's renewable energy: Legislation allowing the solar panel tax credit to be used by apartment houses, and not just single-family homes. Ambitious but unrealistic policy proposal for the city's renewable energy: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's idea to put wind turbines on the city's bridges and skyscrapers.  (Photo: The derailed Staten Island Railway train. (Photo: Mary DiBiase Blaich for The New York Times))   Staten Island transportation high: The Staten Island ferry water rescue of a missing schoolteacher who had jumped into the river. Staten Island transportation low: A car on a Staten Island Railway train derails in Tottenville.  Litigation over a medical procedure on male anatomy: A lawsuit over a forced rectal exam in an emergency room. Litigation over a religious procedure on male anatomy: A libel suit over whether a man was indeed circumcised.   Bizarre animal-napping of a commonplace creature in New York City: A pigeon abduction on the streets of Chinatown. (We were there. We witnessed it!) Bizarre animal-napping of an unusual creature in New York City: The theft of a two-headed turtle from a Brooklyn pet store.  (Photo: A two-headed turtle was stolen in August from a pet store in Brooklyn. (Photo: Sean Casey Animal Rescue))   Shuttering of a restaurant linked to a worldwide celebrity: Cafe La Fortuna, an old haunt for John Lennon on the Upper West Side. Opening of a restaurant linked to a worldwide celebrity: Five Leaves, Heath Ledger's Brooklyn restaurant-bar, which was opened by a friend after the actor's death in January.  Most controversial agreement between Mayor Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn: The change in term limits, allowing the mayor to seek a third term. Most controversial dispute between Mayor Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn: After the mayor's announcement that the city would not distribute $400 tax rebate checks, Ms. Quinn threatened a legal challenge.   Intellectual property dispute involving apples: Apple's legal challenge to the GreenNYC logo, claiming that the looped green apple would cause "consumer confusion resulting in damage and injury" to the Cupertino-based consumer electronics company. Intellectual property dispute involving muggles: J. K. Rowling's successful suit to block publication of the "The Harry Potter Lexicon" because it was based on "wholesale theft of 17 years of my hard work."  (Photo: A job fair at the Pierre Hotel in November drew a large crowd. (Photo: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times))   Long line reflecting economic shifts: Job-seekers flocking to the Pierre Hotel on Fifth Avenue for a daylong job fair in November. Long lines reflecting political shifts: New Yorkers clamoring for historic Nov. 5 issues of newspapers commemorating Barack Obama's election as president of the United States.  New York politician who revealed marital infidelities with the most control: Governor Paterson, who held a noontime news conference one day after taking office to acknowledge that he and his wife had had affairs in their 15-year marriage. New York politician who revealed marital infidelities with the least control: Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Staten Island Republican whose arrest for drunken driving led to an admission that he and a former Air Force lieutenant colonel had a young daughter together.  Most hyped opening signifying a new era for public bathrooms: Madison Square Park's pay toilet, which was heralded in a toilet-paper cutting ceremony that included Janette Sadik-Khan, the transportation commissioner; Adrian Benepe, the parks commissioner; and Daniel L. Doctoroff, the departing deputy mayor for economic development. Most low-key opening signifying a new era for public bathrooms: The Grand Central Terminal waiting room bathrooms, which, after renovations, were quietly designated for women only.  Horizontal political protest that stopped traffic: Carefully orchestrated demonstrations at busy intersections in Manhattan and Brooklyn after the acquittal of three New York City police detectives in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell in 2006. Vertical political protest that stopped traffic: The scalings of The New York Times's Midtown building to draw attention to global warming, raise awareness of malaria and advocate for the aggressive isolation and destruction of Al Qaeda.  Outlandish valet parking proposal, yet to be put into effect: The bike valet to help with commuters' bike parking problems. Outlandish valet parking proposal, already in effect: The stroller valet at the Prospect Park Y.M.C.A. in Park Slope.  A newsworthy ailment with common symptoms: The norovirus, a highly contagious stomach virus that pushed up emergency visits in New York City this fall. It causes vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, stomach cramping, fever, chills, aches and tiredness. A newsworthy ailment with uncommon symptoms: "Late-filing syndrome," which a lawyer for Charles J. O'Byrne, formerly the top aide to Governor Paterson, partly explained Mr. O'Byrne's failure to pay taxes for five years.  Tragedy related to the the Mets' old stadium: A 36-year-old man died at Shea Stadium after he fell over the side of an escalator and plunged more than 30 feet. Tragedy related to the Mets' new stadium: The $900 million ballpark will still be named Citi Field, although the megabank staved off its own imminent collapse through taxpayer-financed bailouts.  Occupational fatality in a financial collapse: The death, apparently by suicide, of Rene Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet, a prominent hedge fund manager who invested with Bernard L. Madoff, after the implosion of the $50 billion Ponzi scheme Mr. Madoff is accused of orchestrating. Occupational fatalities in construction collapses: Six construction workers were killed in two separate crane failures in March and May.  Genuine attack by a financial guy in a gym: A Manhattan stockbroker, Christopher Carter, was charged with  attacking another man in the gym for grunting. He was acquitted. Apocryphal attack by a financial guy in a gym: The Lehman Brothers chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr.,  was reportedly knocked off his treadmill the day after he announced that his firm had gone bankrupt. Lehman officials said the reports weren't true.  Any other suggestions, readers?
abstract: City Room reflects back at 2008, a year of collapses, resignations and waterfalls.

headline.main: The Good and Bad of 2008

snippet: Dinner with Martino Gamper is a do-it-yourself affair.
lead_paragraph: Richard Wright, of the Chicago auction house Wright, proves that great design transcends categories — whether it’s a high-concept chair or a humble hors d’oeuvre. When Wright hosted a dinner party for the Italian furniture designer Martino Gamper, he turned to Nils Norén, of the French Culinary Institute in New York, who explained that the evening’s theme was “taking a familiar product, deconstructing it and turning it into something incredible.” Norén was referring to the topsy-turvy menu — his “pigs in a blanket” consisted of brioche-wrapped lamb set on top of coconut, peanut mustard and apples that had been vacuum-infused with curry oil — but he might as well have been describing Gamper’s work.

snippet: As head of the newly merged Sirius XM Radio, Mel Karmazin faces the task of integrating two companies and finding hundreds of millions of dollars in cost cuts.
lead_paragraph: The The ongoing struggles of Ford, General Motors and Chrysler aren't making Mel Karmazin's job any easier.  As head of the newly merged Sirius XM Radio, Mr. Karmazin faces the task of integrating two companies and finding hundreds of millions of dollars in cost cuts. And as DealBook recently noted, sales of new cars -- where many of the company's radios get installed -- are in a free fall. So, too, is Sirius XM's stock, which closed Wednesday just a few pennies above its 52-week low of $1.26 a share.  A marketing professor from Wharton has a few radical suggestions for Mr. Karmazin about what he should do next.   The professor, Peter Fader, said in the latest edition of Knowledge@Wharton that Sirius should get rid of its current name -- or, rather, both of them -- move away from cars and try to bill itself as a music and entertainment service.  Here's how he put it to Knowledge@Wharton:   Come up with a proposition that can compete with the iPod [...] I'm calling for a marketing makeover. Dump both names because both are tightly linked to satellite radio. The company should be saying, 'Here's a music and entertainment service that's available on every platform every place. And it's commercial free.'  These days, the air is full of unsolicited suggestions for Mr. Karmazin, who once ran CBS. Last month, he exuded confidence as he told DealBook that he was encouraged by the fact that more than half of new-car buyers were choosing to install Sirius.  But many people think that cars will not be enough.   A few weeks ago, an analyst at Citigroup expressed enthusiasm about some kind of collaboration with Apple. He wrote: "Reports of a new Internet streaming application that would allow Sirius XM users to get content on their iPhones and other portable devices are now emerging and highlight that [the company's] value lies in its content and not its hardware or infrastructure."  It's not clear whether Mr. Karmazin will take any of these suggestions to heart. But Sirius XM has billions of dollars of debt that may need to be refinanced next year, so whatever he does, he may need to do it soon.  Go to Article from Knowledge@Wharton>> Go to Previous Column from DealBook>>
abstract: As head of the newly merged Sirius XM Radio, Mel Karmazin faces the task of integrating two companies and finding hundreds of millions of dollars in cost cuts.

headline.main: Major Changes Are Suggested for Sirius XM Radio
headline.print_headline: Major Changes Are Suggested for Sirius XM Radio

lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the tombstone that did it. Even as Wall Street burned, Silicon Valley seemed strangely sanguine. Then a PowerPoint presentation from Sequoia Capital prophesying Armageddon – featuring an “R.I.P. Good Times” headstone – made the rounds. A month later, venture capital firms are slashing investments and counseling portfolio companies to cut jobs. Sequoia’s warning may reflect the technology industry’s woes, but it’s more notable for what it says about venture capital.

lead_paragraph: Love was the theme of the evening at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, when the remarkable Siberian-born baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky performed romances by Tchaikovsky, Medtner and Rachmaninoff. These being Russian songs, there were no apple-cheeked lovers frolicking in springtime, but instead a torrent of gloom and heartache. Mr. Hvorostovsky used the infinite shadings of his luxuriously dark and dusky voice to illuminate the yearning nuances of bitterness and regret.

snippet: Forget the speculation. Dell has been advertising its showdown with Apple all along.
lead_paragraph: CLARIFICATION 5:55 p.m. - The story below references a Dell ad placed in UptownLife magazine. The online version of that ad, which has since been removed, appeared to include both an image from Dell and text. A Dell spokesman, Bob Kaufman, said that Dell was only confirming the "Adamo by Dell" image and not the text, which is quoted in this post.   Brett Wright, the co-founder of Uptown Media, the parent company of Uptownlife.net, has declined to comment on the Dell ad or why the text was removed.  All the speculation about Dell's coming Adamo computer appears somewhat comical once you learn that the company's confirmation of the product has been sitting in plain sight.   Last week, I spotted what looked like a blog post from the luxury magazine UptownLife, discussing a future laptop from Dell possibly thinner than Apple's MacBook Air.  "Rumor has it that Dell is coming out with a computer called Adamo that will rival the MacBook Air," the blog post read. "At press time, the company was keeping the product tightly under wraps, but PC users rejoice - word on the street is that something cool is coming your way."  After my Bits post about Adamo appeared, UptownLife pulled its post down, and Dell refused to discuss the exact nature of the product with reporters. This left most publications guessing about Adamo, saying it could be anything from a thin laptop to perhaps another netbook or a music player.   But it struck me as curious that UptownLife would remove its post – that is, unless the post was actually a Dell advertisement in disguise.   On Tuesday, the Dell spokesman, Mr. Kaufman, confirmed that the Adamo blurb art was in fact a Dell ad. So, it's Dell that has been talking about a product that will "rival the MacBook Air" all along. The UptownLife Web site just made things tricky by lumping blog posts and ads together without making any distinction between the two. (As the clarification notes, Dell is now only confirming the Adamo by Dell image and not the text discussing the rival to the MacBook Air.)  "We did this to wake up the personal computing category and create some buzz," Mr. Kaufman said.   It's expected that Dell will reveal its super-thin laptop at the Consumer Electronics trade show next month in Las Vegas. Then it will be up to Dell to live up to the buzz it has created.
abstract: Forget the speculation. Dell has been advertising its showdown with Apple all along.

headline.main: Dell's MacBook Air Rival Confirmed by . . . Dell
headline.print_headline: Dell's MacBook Air Rival Confirmed by . . . Dell

snippet: Bedtimes be adjusted - there was no way the kids were missing Barack Obama's speech.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Illustration by Barry Falls)   "But Mom, it's historic."   So say my children whenever they want to stay up far too late.   Usually the history-making event involves bats and bases. (I find myself rooting against the Yankees in recent years so that my kids will actually sleep in October.)   Sometimes it is the Academy awards, or the series finale of their favorite television show. This summer, the combination of Michael Phelps swimming past midnight followed by the back-to-back political conventions, meant a lot of bleary eyes at our house. And this morning we all yawned our way through breakfast. Because there was no way they were missing Barack Obama's speech.  One of the pieces of parenting that took me by surprise was the making of history. I knew I would treasure their personal stories — first steps and words, milestones and discoveries. But I hadn't focused on the history being made around them as they grew, and how outside events would become part of their traditions, threads in their lifelong narratives.   I grew up on my parents' histories. My father's memories of Roosevelt's words on the radio on December 7, 1941. My mother's stories of watching in horror as Ruby shot Oswald on live television.   And I have long told my boys tales of my own. Of sitting in a hot crowded camp gym and squinting at a small black-and-white set as a man took a step onto the moon. Of writing, in careful block print, to Richard Nixon, asking him to please resign. Of glancing up at the television as I walked on a treadmill at the gym one evening and watching a wall in Germany being taken apart one chunk at a time.   Yet the fact that I was watching my sons live their own history did not really hit me until 9/11, when Evan, only 9, said somberly, "I will be telling my grandchildren what I was doing today." He had the same thought a few weeks ago, when, staring at a graph of the Dow plummeting he wondered, "will we talk about this the way our grandparents talk about the Depression?"   Of course I let them watch last night. We piled onto the couch, covered ourselves with blankets and "toasted" the winner with our own election-night tradition — a slice of apple pie.   I might not be around when they tell their own teenagers of the night they saw the first African-American elected President. But I will be there. That's what a family is — a string of shared memories woven into an intimate history.
abstract: Bedtimes be adjusted - there was no way the kids were missing Barack Obama's speech.

headline.main: Watching History With My Kids
headline.print_headline: Watching History With My Kids

snippet: For the last few weeks, Manhattan’s been blanketed by mysterious monochromatic ads: “See The World Through Ana’s Eyes,” they’ve teased. This week, they’ve been swapped out for brightly colored versions blasting, “See The World Through Ana Tzarev’s...
abstract: For the last few weeks, Manhattan’s been blanketed by mysterious monochromatic ads: “See The World Through Ana’s Eyes,” they’ve teased. This week, they’ve been swapped out for brightly colored versions blasting, “See The World Through Ana Tzarev’s Eyes.” But who is Ana Tzarev, and why is her vision worth a multimillion-dollar ad campaign? In fact, Tzarev is the owner of the soon-to-open Ana Tzarev Gallery on West 57th Street. But unlike Goodman or Gladstone, Tzarev is not a gallerina; she’s an artist. She has masterminded the 15,000-square-foot space, complete with an Apple store-like elevator at its core, as a retail temple dedicated solely to showcasing her own work (and, occasionally, that of her sister).

headline.main: Have You Seen the World Through Ana’s Eyes?

lead_paragraph: Devotees of the iPhone have a new place to find information about which hot new applications might be on the way.   On Monday, Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, the venture capital firm that is investing its $100 million iFund in mobile applications for the iPhone and iPod touch, unveiled iFundVC, a new blog on the iFund.   "The purpose is to share (and hear) perspectives around the iPhone and emerging open mobile ecosystem. We've been blown away by the amount of entrepreneurial activity in mobile," wrote Matt Murphy, the Kleiner partner who oversees the fund. The blog will be a place for a dialogue about trends in mobile technology, and Kleiner partners and executives will contribute to it.   Laura Holson profiled Mr. Murphy in the Times last month. She reported that Mr. Murphy has been searching for mobile start-ups for seven years, but found it difficult until the iPhone came along. Everything has changed since then. The iFund has received 2,700 business plans from mobile entrepreneurs in six months, Mr. Murphy said on the blog. That is 20 times what the firm received in the similar period last year.   Kleiner, a venerable Silicon Valley firm that backed Google, Amazon.com and America Online, has invested $30 million in five mobile start-ups since March 6, when it started the fund in collaboration with Apple:   Pelago uses Whrrl to enable users to track their friends' location and share reviews of restaurants and events. Ng:moco makes iPhone games. iControl lets users monitor their homes while they are away. GOGII uses text messaging for social interaction and marketing. The fifth company, as yet unnamed, will let users access virtual worlds through their phones, Ms. Holson reported.  iPhone users are clamoring for new applications. They downloaded 60 million of them in 30 days, Mr. Murphy said on the blog -- more than were downloaded to phones by all other carriers in the United States in a quarter. That is especially dramatic considering that there are 12 million iPhone handsets compared to 250 million non-iPhones.   "The impact of openness is now undeniable," Mr. Murphy wrote. "The keys: open the mobile eco-system, solve the discovery problem, and deliver great apps ... users flock to download them."   Topics to watch, Mr. Murphy said: Whether and how other carriers open their application stores to developers and the more sophisticated next generation of iPhone applications in the pipeline.
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm that is investing its $100 million iFund in applications for the iPhone and iPod touch, has a new blog that will discuss trends in mobile.

headline.main: Kleiner Perkins Starts an iPhone Blog
headline.print_headline: Kleiner Perkins Starts an iPhone Blog

lead_paragraph: Anyone reading this blog would probably say “I love books.” Sure you do: You have stacks and stacks at work and at home, in every room, covering every possible horizontal surface. You never leave the house without a book in your bag. You have literary quotes tacked to your wall, your Amazon wish list never falls below 50 items, you could spend hours — days! — lost in the stacks at the Strand or Powell’s or Green Apple or Foyles. You’ve named a child after your favorite author. Whatever.

snippet: Bedtimes be adjusted - there was no way the kids were missing Barack Obama's speech.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Illustration by Barry Falls)   "But Mom, it's historic."   So say my children whenever they want to stay up far too late.   Usually the history-making event involves bats and bases. (I find myself rooting against the Yankees in recent years so that my kids will actually sleep in October.)   Sometimes it is the Academy awards, or the series finale of their favorite television show. This summer, the combination of Michael Phelps swimming past midnight followed by the back-to-back political conventions, meant a lot of bleary eyes at our house. And this morning we all yawned our way through breakfast. Because there was no way they were missing Barack Obama's speech.  One of the pieces of parenting that took me by surprise was the making of history. I knew I would treasure their personal stories — first steps and words, milestones and discoveries. But I hadn't focused on the history being made around them as they grew, and how outside events would become part of their traditions, threads in their lifelong narratives.   I grew up on my parents' histories. My father's memories of Roosevelt's words on the radio on December 7, 1941. My mother's stories of watching in horror as Ruby shot Oswald on live television.   And I have long told my boys tales of my own. Of sitting in a hot crowded camp gym and squinting at a small black-and-white set as a man took a step onto the moon. Of writing, in careful block print, to Richard Nixon, asking him to please resign. Of glancing up at the television as I walked on a treadmill at the gym one evening and watching a wall in Germany being taken apart one chunk at a time.   Yet the fact that I was watching my sons live their own history did not really hit me until 9/11, when Evan, only 9, said somberly, "I will be telling my grandchildren what I was doing today." He had the same thought a few weeks ago, when, staring at a graph of the Dow plummeting he wondered, "will we talk about this the way our grandparents talk about the Depression?"   Of course I let them watch last night. We piled onto the couch, covered ourselves with blankets and "toasted" the winner with our own election-night tradition — a slice of apple pie.   I might not be around when they tell their own teenagers of the night they saw the first African-American elected President. But I will be there. That's what a family is — a string of shared memories woven into an intimate history.
abstract: Bedtimes be adjusted - there was no way the kids were missing Barack Obama's speech.

headline.main: Watching History With My Kids
headline.print_headline: Watching History With My Kids

snippet: There’s no better place to sample the sights, sounds and tastes of Ramadan in Paris than in the working class muslim neighborhood of La Goutte d’Or in the 18th arrondissment.
lead_paragraph: There’s no better place to sample the sights, sounds and tastes of Ramadan in Paris than in the working class muslim neighborhood of La Goutte d’Or in the 18th arrondissment. The area, near the metro stop Barbes Rochechouart, is mainly North African, waves of who came in the 1950s and 1960s to work as laborers. During the Algerian war, the neighborhood was so heavily populated with Algerians that it became the headquarters of the FLN, the Algerian National Liberation Front . But now it’s filled with restaurants and shops.

snippet: A crunchy tomato with an intense flavor is a surprise in Italy.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Tomatoes, from left: big cherries/small plums; a Genovese; and the Raf, from Spain. (Mark Bittman)) I ate a lot of raw vegetables on this swing through France, Italy, and Spain -- some days, in fact, my stomach felt like a juicer. But when I go to markets I have to shop, and when I don't have a stove, I wind up eating uncooked beets, fennel, carrots, celery, green beans -- I love the big flat romanos -- and now even artichokes.   I didn't see really nice-looking tomatoes, though, until we got to Rome, where I bought two kinds. On the left here are some sort of big cherries/small plums; they were tender, ripe, sweet -- decent, not super-complex flavor. On the right were a kind that looked like a variety I used to grow, but found to be completely different: Nearly as hard as an apple, they had amazing intensity -- almost like tomato paste in crunchy form. I could not stop eating them. (They were, raw, better than any dish served to me at the fancy restaurant I was taken to that same night, one not worth writing about.)   They stumped me. One, I didn't know what they were; two, if they were this hard, why weren't they shipped, preferably directly to my house; three, who used them, and for what?   I was about to post a "Help! Please!" to Bitten, but I was also meeting Mario Batali in Spain, so I brought the remaining tomato over. He called it Genovese (though it was clearly grown in the south), and said it was a salad tomato; that Italians sliced it very, very thin, to mitigate its crunchiness; and that it was served with lettuce.   Makes sense to me, but I wish I had a case to play with. I want to see if they ever soften, and I want to cook with them. Next time.   Meanwhile, in Madrid's Mercado de Paz, a lovely neighborhood market (there are many), I encountered -- as I did last year at this time -- the quite similar Raf tomato (pictured on the right), which I believe is from Valencia (I was told the word was Valenciana in any case). Also highly prized, also fairly expensive (the equivalent of $3 or $4 a pound, which is really not all that bad, considering), also quite crunchy. Given that these experiences happened in the month of March, I was ready to move to southern Europe.   Needless to say I came home. I'll tidy up with a couple of remaining thoughts from the trip, and then back to reality. Also, stay tuned for a slide show of photos from the market.
abstract: A crunchy tomato with an intense flavor is a surprise in Italy.

headline.main: Discovering an Intense, Crunchy Tomato
headline.print_headline: Discovering an Intense, Crunchy Tomato

snippet: Andrew Giuliani hit some balls on Randalls Island and talked about his suit over his place on the university golf team.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Andrew Giuliani, the son of the former mayor and presidential candidate, has filed a lawsuit against Duke University. The suit contends that he was unfairly removed from the golf team. (Photo: Rob Bennett for The New York Times))  His father made it big in politics, but Andrew Giuliani's dreams veer toward sports, he explained as he smacked golf balls on Randalls Island on Thursday. That's one reason he said he had little choice but to sue Duke University where he is a student, and its head golf coach for pushing him off the varsity golf team this spring.  Mr. Giuliani, who is 22, is the older of two children of Rudolph W. Giuliani and his former wife, Donna Hanover.  On Wednesday, the younger Giuliani filed a lawsuit [pdf] in federal court in Durham, N.C., accusing the university of bad faith by "aggressively" recruiting him as a high school student to play for Duke, then dashing his dreams by taking steps during his junior year in college to dislodge him from the team.   In the lawsuit, he acknowledges that he may have misbehaved in February by flipping his putter a few feet, throwing and breaking a club, gunning his engine out of a parking lot and tossing an apple at a teammate's face in a skirmish.  Rather than "quibble" about the details, the student said he had apologized for his own conduct, and said it pales next to the "bizarre" treatment he received from the school once Coach Orrin Daniel Vincent III took over the men's golf program last summer.  Taking it all in on Thursday, as the student practiced his swing before reporters and photographers at the driving range on Randalls Island, was his mother. "It's not something you're going to be happy about,'' said Ms. Hanover, the TV personality and actress. Her divorce from Rudolph Giuliani became final in 2002, and in 2003 she married Edwin A. Oster, a high school boyfriend. (Mr. Giuliani also remarried, to Judith Nathan that same year.)  Ms. Hanover added that under no condition would Andrew be changing schools. "Oh, he's going to finish at Duke,'' she said.  Duke, which had endured much unfavorable publicity when it suspended members of its men's lacrosse team for perceived misconduct and ultimately had to apologize, issued a brief statement that read: "Duke's coaches and student athletes are held to the highest standards, which include a strong commitment to fairness for all participants in our sports programs. We intend to vigorously defend this lawsuit.''  A revised and updated version of this article was published in Friday's final print edition.
abstract: Andrew Giuliani hit some balls on Randalls Island and talked about his suit over his place on the university golf team.

headline.main: Giuliani’s Son Discusses Duke Lawsuit
headline.print_headline: Giuliani's Son Discusses Duke Lawsuit

snippet: On a quest for a good rosé that costs less than $20, I tried Mateus. Remember that?
lead_paragraph: In the last year, I have moved away a bit from my longtime enjoyment of red wine because of the morning-after effects, and started experimenting with other drinks, most notably whites. Along with this move has come a newfound affection for rosé, which is made not by mixing white and red grapes, as is sometimes thought, but by allowing relatively brief contact between skins and juice, just enough to impart a bit of color and body. The best rosés are much more akin to white than red (this includes the allergic reaction department), copper-colored (though there are a range of enjoyable colors) and, usually, more crisp than fruity. I like them bone dry.
abstract: On a quest for a good rosé that costs less than $20, I tried Mateus. Remember that?

headline.main: On Rosé

snippet: A dinner at Les Papilles, a much-heralded restaurant in Paris, showed signs of greatness.
lead_paragraph: I try never to visit Paris without at least attempting to intersect with my bi-continental friend Dorie Greenspan, the food writer, whom I see in New York with some frequency. She spends enough time in Paris to really know what’s going on (check out her site: www.doriegreenspan.com), she knows how to eat, and her French is 10 times better than mine. So when she’s there, and I’m there, it’s a no-brainer. Fortunately, on this trip she was, and on the second-to-last night I was in town she took me to the much-heralded Les Papilles. (It’s right around the corner from the Luxembourg Gardens at 30 rue Gay-Lussac; 011 33 1 43 25 20 79.)
