snippet: Traditional holiday foods cost a whole lot more when you buy them in the organic aisle.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Cooking organic? It may cost you. (Barbara P. Fernandez for The New York Times))    Most people know that eating organic costs more. But according to SmartMoney.com, Thanksgiving diners may pay as much as $100 extra for an organic holiday meal.  The financial advice Web site went shopping to find out how much extra consumers have to pay to get organic versions of traditional holiday foods. Creating a shopping list for a traditional menu to serve eight people, they selected organic and nonorganic foods from a Whole Foods, Associated Supermarket and a Food Emporium, all located in New York City.  "Overall, the organic version of our turkey-day menu for eight people — including dinner rolls, a salad and three bottles of organic wine — totaled $295.36. That puts the organic premium for the meal at $126.35, or 75 percent, compared with the same shopping list filled with nonorganic options,'' wrote SmartMoney.  Here's a sample comparing the prices of organic and nonorganic Thanksgiving foods.   Turkey (20 pounds) $99.80 vs. $23.80  Vanilla ice cream (3 quarts) $21.87 vs. $15.98  Yams (5 lbs.) $9.95 vs. $3.95  Broccoli (2 lbs.) $5.98 vs. $3.98  Heavy whipping cream (2 pints) $5.58 vs. $4.00  2 cans of pumpkin filling $5.00 vs. $3.19  1 bag cranberries $4.99 vs. $2.49     So is it worth it? Health experts are divided on whether consumers derive any real health benefits by choosing organic foods. For consumers on tight budgets who want to buy organic, the Environmental Working Group recommends a strategic approach. Choose organic foods for those products that typically have high pesticide residues, like apples, bell peppers, celery and strawberries. But for commercially-farmed products that have low pesticide levels, like avocados, onions and pineapples, you can save money by buying nonorganic varieties.  Pediatrician Dr. Alan Greene, of the popular Web site www.drgreene.com, offers an organic prescription listing the best organic items for parents to choose. Topping the list is milk and milk products. One recent United States Department of Agriculture survey found pesticides in about 30 percent of conventional milk samples and low levels in only one organic sample.   To read more about the high price of an organic holiday meal and to see more food comparisons read the full story at SmartMoney.com.  Every weekday through Jan. 2, the Well blog will feature "30 Days of Holiday Eating,'' a new series that will include a daily tip, tidbit or insight about holiday food.
abstract: Traditional holiday foods cost a whole lot more when you buy them in the organic aisle.

headline.main: Paying Extra for an Organic Thanksgiving
headline.print_headline: Paying Extra for an Organic Thanksgiving

snippet: An unconventional collaboration between architects and academics in New York is meant to make sustainable design more of a reality.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Students in the Center for Architecture Science and Ecology in the Skidmore, Owings & Merrill office at 14 Wall Street. (Photos: David W. Dunlap/The New York Times))   Sustainable design is architecture's mom-and-apple-pie issue. Who could be against it?  Who would oppose the idea of buildings that heat, cool, ventilate and illuminate themselves -- providing pure air and water in the bargain -- by taking advantage of environmental forces, without depleting natural resources?  Yet in the real world, practicing architects generally cannot take the chance on untested technology. And academics typically don't have actual construction sites on which to test their sustainable ideas.  That is why the architectural firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has joined with the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute to establish a collaborative practice known as the Center for Architecture Science and Ecology, or CASE.  In the city, CASE is housed in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill's office at 14 Wall Street. (Its space used to be the accounting department.) There are 24 students and six faculty members in residence. The program has been operating about a year, but is to be formally introduced Friday in a reception at the top of 7 World Trade Center. Until now, the unconventional collaboration was going through a "shakedown cruise," said Carl Galioto, the Skidmore partner in charge of the technical group in New York.  "S.O.M.'s motivation is that we want to be at the leading edge of technology," Mr. Galioto said. "We don't want to wait for products to come to market." Conceivably, the Skidmore and Rensselaer teams will work together on developing construction methods and materials that can be put quickly to use.  (Photo: Walls in the CASE office show the variety of structural exploration taking place there.) Anna Dyson, an associate professor at Rensselaer and the director of CASE, said, "It's really important to connect with professionals who are working with complex problems on a day-to-day basis."  As an example, she and Mr. Galioto cited a master planning project involving the air rights for an interstate highway in Washington, D.C. Might it be possible, if the highway is decked over, to construct "eco-chimneys" in which plant materials would help purify the exhaust air coming up from the tunnel-like underpass?  CASE participants will explore the use of natural dehumidifying materials, the naturally cooling properties of terra cotta walls and ways in which a structure can be modified to harness wind energy.  Though "green design" sometimes seems to have a flavor-of-the-month quality, Mr. Galioto said that with ever-growing demand and ever-diminishing resources, "sustainable design will be compelling for a long time to come."
abstract: An unconventional collaboration between architects and academics in New York is meant to make sustainable design more of a reality.

headline.main: Green Buildings for the Real World
headline.print_headline: Designing Green Buildings for the Real World

snippet: Netflix has turned mailing DVD movies into a head start in the world of digital video.
lead_paragraph: I've been thinking a lot about how Netflix -- that odd combination of Internet ordering, the post office and DVDs -- may actually be one of the companies best positioned to take advantage of online video.  (Photo: Netflix rental. (Credit: Paul Sakuma/AP)) Follow me on this, because I think there is an important clue about how technology gets adopted.   In the short term, Netflix is being hit hard by the economic slowdown. It said Monday that it added far fewer subscribers in the third quarter than it had promised investors. Its shares are down about 17 percent this week.   But the company is still an improbable success story, fending off many assaults from Blockbuster. Netflix now has 8.7 million subscribers, and its more cautious forecast is to add 278,000 to 578,000 in the fourth quarter. At worst, that's a pace of 1 million new subscribers a year -- not shabby for any business.   What I'm paying attention to is the company's still-small incursion into delivering video over the Internet. Until now, Netflix had a collection of about 10,000 older movies and TV episodes. Last week it added a catalog of 2,500 movies (mainly one to five years old) from the Starz cable network.   There is an interesting back story to that deal.   Starz and Netflix have been the two most prominent rivals trying to sell subscription services with access to movies and TV shows. That is the rough online equivalent of a pay cable channel, like HBO or, of course, Starz. It's different from the online pay-per-view model of Apple and Blockbuster's MovieLink, which compete more with DVD rental shops.   Starz's $9.95 service, called Vongo, flopped despite a lot of marketing. Since Starz, which is owned by John Malone's Liberty Media, had spent a lot of money buying the Internet rights to the movies it also shows on cable, the best way to make a return on the investment was to sell the rights to Netflix. (The terms of that deal were not disclosed; typically, Netflix pays a fee to the owner of a movie every time one of its customers watches it online.)   Vongo, and so many other online movie services, have been spot-on in their vision of the future: It is very clear that ultimately we will be able to watch pretty much any program over the Internet if we want to. But it is much harder to figure out how to get from here to there, especially because of the limits on movie rights that Hollywood imposes under its existing business system.   Vongo floundered because it was too much to ask for people to pay $10 a month for a rather random and limited selection of movies.   The key idea -- and it is no surprise when you say it this way -- is that businesses can only move toward the future if they satisfy their customers at every step along the way. People with lives to lead have little interest in playing with new technology until the bugs are worked out. That means products have to be really easy to use and not have weird disappointments.  That's why Netflix has such an advantage over nearly any Internet video start-up. Its DVD business is comprehensive and satisfies customers. Customers see its current, half-baked online video service, as more of a free bonus than a disappointment. Over time, as it adds more content and improves the technology, Netflix can figure out if it needs to charge more for online video and whether it can offer an online-only service without DVDs by mail.   Netflix also increasingly has leverage because it is one of the few Internet companies that has persuaded customers to pay it a regular monthly fee. One of the biggest blocks to moving some of the best programming from cable networks to the Web is that the only viable model so far has been advertising; cable programmers are used to earning money both from ads and from a cut of the subscription fees collected by cable systems.   Netflix is already using some of its subscription revenue to acquire rights to cable programming, such as a recent deal with the Disney Channel to let customers watch shows like "Hannah Montana." Over time, it could add more content, exploring whether customers find value in paying for a bundle of programs delivered online.   There is a similar dynamic that gives Netflix an interesting edge in the living room as well. The company has a partial stake in Roku, a company that has made a small $99 box that lets you watch the Netflix online videos on your television set. The company won't give out details but it says it is on track to sell hundreds of thousands of the devices this year.   Compare the proposition of a Roku box for a Netflix subscriber ($99 up front and nothing additional per month over the existing subscription) to the highly promoted video box from Vudu, which costs $299 and $3 to $6 per movie. Yes, Vudu has newer films, but its catalog is still a bit random. I just don't see how that company establishes a big base of happy customers now to get the critical mass it needs to cut deals with Hollywood.   Roku, meanwhile is now cutting deals with other content companies –- including broadcast and cable network groups -- to offer other sorts of programming on its box. My point here is that without the connection to Netflix and its 8.7 million subscribers, Roku would never have been able to achieve escape velocity on its own.   I'm not saying that the big company always has the advantage. More often than not, the nimble start-up has beaten the entrenched giant. But a successful company that can build upon satisfied customers has a big advantage over a start-up without that base.   Indeed, the other serious players in online video also draw from strength in other markets. Apple is the odds-on favorite so far because of its momentum in hardware and music. Google's YouTube and Hulu are the leaders in advertising-supported Web video and may be able to add premium services as well. And some cable companies, especially Comcast, are looking to extend their existing subscription businesses and relationships with Hollywood onto the Web.   But I think it is interesting that they are all now competing with Netflix, a company whose success began with a knack for efficiently mailing a lot of envelopes.
abstract: Netflix has turned mailing DVD movies into a head start in the world of digital video.

headline.main: Head Start for Netflix in Online Video Race
headline.print_headline: Why Netflix May Be an Online Video Leader

snippet: The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has started an education campaign noting that a typical adult needs no more than 2,000 calories a day.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: This poster is part of an education campaign noting that a typical adult needs no more than 2,000 calories a day. (Photo: New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene) )  These days, the New York City subways seem to be filled with advertisements carrying prominent, unmissable public-service messages: Watch out for second-hand smoke. Call 311 if you see a homeless person who needs help. Be on the lookout for signs of child abuse. Don't harass women.   (And we're not even talking about the new, wraparound advertisements for the History Channel.)  Now the authorities have a new message for subway riders: Watch those calories.  A new public education campaign by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene -- five advertisements, which will be posted in 1,000 subway cars -- struck a variety of themes.   One argument made is that some meals are just too big. One ad shows a plate with a chicken burrito and full toppings: tomato, guacamole and sour cream (1,170 calories). Another shows a box of fried chicken, with a biscuit, macaroni and cheese and a soda (1,210 calories). "If this is lunch, is there room for a dinner?" the ads ask.  Other ads suggest smaller portions. For example, getting a double cheeseburger with small fries and a diet soda (670 calories) can be a vast improvement over the same cheeseburger with large fries and regular soda (1,250 calories). The motto: "Choose less, weigh less."   Another tactic used in the campaign is surprise. Who knew that a tuna sub sandwich (530 calories) was so much richer than a roast beef sub (290 calories)?   Then there is the guilt factor. One ad shows a giant apple-raisin muffin (470 calories) and declares: "Healthy snack? Maybe not."   There is an online component to the ad campaign. Cathy Nonas, a dietitian who directs the Health Department's physical activity and nutrition program, will host a blog on calorie counting later this week at nyc.gov/health.  The city has taken action to ban trans fats and require restaurants to post calorie counts on their menu boards and believes that more information is better. The Health Department said in a press release:   Health Department surveys have shown that when restaurant patrons use calorie information in deciding what to order, they average nearly 100 fewer calories in each meal purchased. The Health Department estimates that posting calories on menu boards and menus will reduce the number of people who suffer from obesity by 150,000 over the next five years, preventing more than 30,000 cases of diabetes.
abstract: The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has started an education campaign noting that a typical adult needs no more than 2,000 calories a day.

headline.main: Watch Those Calories, Subway Riders
headline.print_headline: Watch Those Calories, City Tells Subway Riders

snippet: Netflix has turned mailing DVD movies into a head start in the world of digital video.
lead_paragraph: I've been thinking a lot about how Netflix -- that odd combination of Internet ordering, the post office and DVDs -- may actually be one of the companies best positioned to take advantage of online video.  (Photo: Netflix rental. (Credit: Paul Sakuma/AP)) Follow me on this, because I think there is an important clue about how technology gets adopted.   In the short term, Netflix is being hit hard by the economic slowdown. It said Monday that it added far fewer subscribers in the third quarter than it had promised investors. Its shares are down about 17 percent this week.   But the company is still an improbable success story, fending off many assaults from Blockbuster. Netflix now has 8.7 million subscribers, and its more cautious forecast is to add 278,000 to 578,000 in the fourth quarter. At worst, that's a pace of 1 million new subscribers a year -- not shabby for any business.   What I'm paying attention to is the company's still-small incursion into delivering video over the Internet. Until now, Netflix had a collection of about 10,000 older movies and TV episodes. Last week it added a catalog of 2,500 movies (mainly one to five years old) from the Starz cable network.   There is an interesting back story to that deal.   Starz and Netflix have been the two most prominent rivals trying to sell subscription services with access to movies and TV shows. That is the rough online equivalent of a pay cable channel, like HBO or, of course, Starz. It's different from the online pay-per-view model of Apple and Blockbuster's MovieLink, which compete more with DVD rental shops.   Starz's $9.95 service, called Vongo, flopped despite a lot of marketing. Since Starz, which is owned by John Malone's Liberty Media, had spent a lot of money buying the Internet rights to the movies it also shows on cable, the best way to make a return on the investment was to sell the rights to Netflix. (The terms of that deal were not disclosed; typically, Netflix pays a fee to the owner of a movie every time one of its customers watches it online.)   Vongo, and so many other online movie services, have been spot-on in their vision of the future: It is very clear that ultimately we will be able to watch pretty much any program over the Internet if we want to. But it is much harder to figure out how to get from here to there, especially because of the limits on movie rights that Hollywood imposes under its existing business system.   Vongo floundered because it was too much to ask for people to pay $10 a month for a rather random and limited selection of movies.   The key idea -- and it is no surprise when you say it this way -- is that businesses can only move toward the future if they satisfy their customers at every step along the way. People with lives to lead have little interest in playing with new technology until the bugs are worked out. That means products have to be really easy to use and not have weird disappointments.  That's why Netflix has such an advantage over nearly any Internet video start-up. Its DVD business is comprehensive and satisfies customers. Customers see its current, half-baked online video service, as more of a free bonus than a disappointment. Over time, as it adds more content and improves the technology, Netflix can figure out if it needs to charge more for online video and whether it can offer an online-only service without DVDs by mail.   Netflix also increasingly has leverage because it is one of the few Internet companies that has persuaded customers to pay it a regular monthly fee. One of the biggest blocks to moving some of the best programming from cable networks to the Web is that the only viable model so far has been advertising; cable programmers are used to earning money both from ads and from a cut of the subscription fees collected by cable systems.   Netflix is already using some of its subscription revenue to acquire rights to cable programming, such as a recent deal with the Disney Channel to let customers watch shows like "Hannah Montana." Over time, it could add more content, exploring whether customers find value in paying for a bundle of programs delivered online.   There is a similar dynamic that gives Netflix an interesting edge in the living room as well. The company has a partial stake in Roku, a company that has made a small $99 box that lets you watch the Netflix online videos on your television set. The company won't give out details but it says it is on track to sell hundreds of thousands of the devices this year.   Compare the proposition of a Roku box for a Netflix subscriber ($99 up front and nothing additional per month over the existing subscription) to the highly promoted video box from Vudu, which costs $299 and $3 to $6 per movie. Yes, Vudu has newer films, but its catalog is still a bit random. I just don't see how that company establishes a big base of happy customers now to get the critical mass it needs to cut deals with Hollywood.   Roku, meanwhile is now cutting deals with other content companies –- including broadcast and cable network groups -- to offer other sorts of programming on its box. My point here is that without the connection to Netflix and its 8.7 million subscribers, Roku would never have been able to achieve escape velocity on its own.   I'm not saying that the big company always has the advantage. More often than not, the nimble start-up has beaten the entrenched giant. But a successful company that can build upon satisfied customers has a big advantage over a start-up without that base.   Indeed, the other serious players in online video also draw from strength in other markets. Apple is the odds-on favorite so far because of its momentum in hardware and music. Google's YouTube and Hulu are the leaders in advertising-supported Web video and may be able to add premium services as well. And some cable companies, especially Comcast, are looking to extend their existing subscription businesses and relationships with Hollywood onto the Web.   But I think it is interesting that they are all now competing with Netflix, a company whose success began with a knack for efficiently mailing a lot of envelopes.
abstract: Netflix has turned mailing DVD movies into a head start in the world of digital video.

headline.main: Head Start for Netflix in Online Video Race
headline.print_headline: Why Netflix May Be an Online Video Leader

snippet: Outrageous!, for example, is a work of talent, originality and vision. It smells deeply artificial in the best sense, intentionally bearing the same relationship to the natural world that Tang does to orange juice. Outrageous! is not a synthetic v...
lead_paragraph: Outrageous!, for example, is a work of talent, originality and vision. It smells deeply artificial in the best sense, intentionally bearing the same relationship to the natural world that Tang does to orange juice. Outrageous! is not a synthetic version of nature but a free-standing creation that refers to the natural world ironically and revels in its own artifice. It is, in fact, the smell of Tang sprinkled on a plate of polyurethane on which sit grapes, apples and pears made of polyvinyl chloride. The scent of kerosene ingeniously adds alarm to the soft, dystopian glow. Frowning, I once said to Sophia Grojsman, who created it for Barneys New York Co-Op, “It makes me think of a Mondrian: rigid, unnatural rectangles of artificially bright colors.” She put her hands on my shoulders and squeezed with delight.

snippet: The government deems its $123 billion bailout of A.I.G. too modest.
lead_paragraph: The worse things look over at insurance giant A.I.G. the bigger the payout from the feds. The Wall Street Journal has the details:     The U.S. government reached a deal Sunday night to scrap its original $123 billion bailout of American International Group Inc. and replace it with a new $150 billion package, according to people familiar with the matter.  While the arrangement stands to considerably ease terms on the faltering insurer, it gives the government an unprecedented role as an actor in financial markets. It could also spark a political backlash, especially from congressional Democrats, because the Treasury, while adding to its AIG obligations, has thus far refused to extend a hand to the struggling Big Three auto makers.    Felix Salmon at Porfolio is amazed at "how spectacularly incompetent A.I.G. has been when it comes to securities lending:    Securities lending is meant to be a no-risk operation. In a repo operation, the long-term owner of a stock — in this case, AIG — will sell it to someone who wants to short it, and charge them interest. They then subsequently buy back the stock at the price they sold it for; the interest is pure profit.  AIG, however, seems to have gotten spectacularly greedy. It took the proceeds from the stock sales, and instead of putting it somewhere safe, invested it in RMBS. Which are now worth 50 cents on the dollar.  This is in a way worse than AIG's misadventures in the CDS market. When AIG Financial Products wrote credit protection, it thought the chances of default were minimal. But investing $42 billion of repo collateral in RMBS? There's no good reason to do that: it's not your money, you can't afford to lose it, so you put it somewhere safe.    "The A.I.G. case constitutes looting," adds Yves Smith at Naked Capitalism:    Executives there are handsomely paid, yet senior management cast a blind eye as one unit earned outsized profits while taking risks that would have driven AIG into bankruptcy were it not for the Fed's rescue. Before you say, "Well, it was just a few bad apples," the biggest single job of senior management in a financial institution ought to be to assure the health and survival of the entity, which means risk management and control is top of the list (it was at Goldman when it was a private firm). Anytime a unit starts reporting very large profits, managers should be all over it like a cheap suit to make sure the earnings are not the product of massive risktaking. It only takes one aggressive trader plus inattentive management to bring down an entire firm, as Nick Leeson demonstrated with Barings.  But the worst is that not only was the initial AIG de facto bankruptcy a case of looting, the government has now decided to aid and abet AIG management in further looting.    And guess who's shop is being ransacked, dear taxpayers ....
abstract: The government deems its $123 billion bailout of A.I.G. too modest.

headline.main: A Bigger Bailout
headline.print_headline: A Bigger Bailout

snippet: Two examples of tech companies that actually handle customer service well.
lead_paragraph: Usually, all we hear about online is complaining. Only the squeaky wheels show up to make their reports. Not a day goes by that some reader doesn't e-mail me to complain about some troubleshooting glitch with a product from Apple, HP, Dell, whatever— "and if you Google it, you'll see that I'm not alone!"   (Yeah? Well, you can Google ANYTHING and find a lot of hits, especially when it concerns a company that sells tens of millions of units a year.)  But anyway, I thought that maybe today I'd offer two examples of companies doing things right.   Canon. I once wrote about the Canon IP90 color printer, which is so small you can keep it on a kitchen counter for printing homework, which is what we do. I love it. Or did, until it totally stopped working after eight months.  So I called the 800 number. The guy walked me through some troubleshooting steps, determined that it was truly broken, and told me I'd have my replacement in three days. The new unit (which he said would be a refurbished unit, but arrived obviously unopened and brand new—meaning it had been returned to a store but never opened) arrived on schedule, complete with a prepaid return-shipping label for the original broken machine. All free, all covered by warranty.  I know that's not especially amazing—isn't that how it's supposed to work? But to me, it's amazing that it does.   Microsoft.  When I reviewed the new Zune music players a couple of weeks ago, I needed a ZunePass subscription to test all of the features. That's where you pay $15 a month for unlimited music downloading from Microsoft's Zune store. A ZunePass makes possible a lot of the cool new features of the new Zune software, like automatic streaming from the Internet and self-updating "channels" of music in the styles you like.  When I went to sign up, I saw an option for a 14-day free trial. It was perfect for my review period, so I signed up.  A few days ago, my e-mail received a note that my trial period was about up, and invited me to convert the account into a paid one. The kicker: "To avoid a possible interruption of your subscription service, please renew your subscription by Tuesday, September 30, 2008."  See the great part here? Unlike every other free-trial program in history, Microsoft does NOT automatically convert you into a paying customer, counting on the fact that people forget to cancel. It's an opt-in system, not opt-out. You have to make an effort to PAY, not an effort to REMEMBER to cancel. It's going to cost Microsoft money this way, but it will gain goodwill (and congratulatory posts like this one).
abstract: Two examples of tech companies that actually handle customer service well.

headline.main: How Some Companies Are Doing It Right

snippet: Detroit's beleaguered automakers have suffered a blow — this time, to their efforts to stave off higher emissions standards for cars and trucks.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: A suit brought by automakers, including General Motors, aimed at blocking tougher emissions standards in Rhode Island, was rejected by a federal court. (Photo: Associated Press)) Detroit's beleaguered automakers suffered another blow on Tuesday — this time, to their efforts to stave off higher emissions standards for cars and trucks.  Several automakers, including DaimlerChrysler and General Motors, had sued in the Federal District Court for Rhode Island to stop that state from following California's efforts to seek greenhouse gas emissions standards that are stricter than those of the federal government. Automakers had already lost similar federal cases in Vermont and California.  Ernest C. Torres, the federal district judge in Rhode Island, ruled that the automakers had already been heard in the Vermont and California cases.  "It is difficult to see what interest the public has in permitting the plaintiffs another bite of the apple in challenging regulations limiting the emission of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere," wrote Judge Torres.     Allowing yet more litigation on the matter would open the door to "costly and vexatious multiple lawsuits, the waste of judicial resources and the risk of inconsistent decisions," he added.   Although Judge Torres ruled against the automakers, he did allow car dealers in Rhode Island to proceed with a similar suit.   Nonetheless, environmentalists cheered the ruling.   Continuing to file suits and appeals is "not only pointless because they keep losing, but it's counterproductive as these guys go to Washington and beg for taxpayer dollars," said David Bookbinder, the chief climate counsel for the Sierra Club, which filed a brief in the case.  Melissa Hoffer, vice president of the Conservation Law Foundation, another party to the proceedings, said that several environmental groups have been urging Congress to condition the bailout on the automakers' dropping these types of suits, an argument also noted in American Lawyer's blog.  Automakers have appealed the rulings in California and Vermont, and auto dealers have filed another similar suit in a federal court in New Mexico.  Charlie Territo, a spokesman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, one of the groups bringing the Rhode Island suit, said he was pleased that the auto dealers' case was permitted to proceed.   He also said that car makers are "committed to enhancing energy security and reducing greenhouse gas emissions and believe the best way to do so is through a single national standard set by the federal government."  The ruling has no immediate impact on automakers. California currently does not have stricter tailpipe standards than the rest of the country. It would like to, but in accordance with the Clean Air Act, the state first needs a waiver from the Environmental Protection Agency, and its efforts have been thwarted by the Bush administration.  Many environmentalists hope and believe that the incoming administration of President-elect Barack Obama will grant California the waiver. Mr. Bookbinder of the Sierra Club said that 13 other states stood ready to adopt California's stricter emissions standards, if and when they are allowed to do so.
abstract: Detroit's beleaguered automakers have suffered a blow — this time, to their efforts to stave off higher emissions standards for cars and trucks.

headline.main: Rhode Island Ruling on Emissions
headline.print_headline: Environmentalists Cheer Rhode Island Court Decision

snippet: Maybe a little less money spent on candy, while a chilling reminder of the economy, is not entirely bad news.
lead_paragraph: While forecasters are busy predicting a slow Christmas shopping season, less noticed is the fact that Halloween is already taking a big hit.  A survey by BabyCenter, an online site for young families, found that parents will be spending 20 percent less on the kid-centric holiday this year. Of the 400 respondents to a BabyCenter survey earlier this week, 75 percent said they will be spending less on candy and 57 percent will be spending less on decorations. There will be fewer store bought costumes and Halloween parties and less adult dressing up and, did I mention, less candy?  As the daughter of an orthodontist, Halloween was a Red Letter Day on my childhood calendar. It was the only day when I was allowed to eat candy with abandon. (Well, not the sticky stuff during the years when I had my braces on. And, being ever the obedient child, I look back and marvel at the fact that I never once snuck a piece of gum or caramel behind Dad's back.)  As a parent, some of the most fun I have had with my children has been on Halloween. Our block is trick-or-treating heaven — a dead end with very little traffic, where everyone knows everyone else. At Klaus and Suzanne's house there is a tent over the driveway, an array of spooky sights and sounds and a buffet of sweets. At Bruce and Carol's house there are elaborately carved pumpkins — some "vomit" out their seedy insides; others spew flame. When my children were younger, there was something delicious about a chilly little hand tucked into mine as they clung to a their bag o' goodies with the other. Now that they are older, they are the ones handing out the candy and pretending to be scared as tiny goblins chirp "trick or treat" at our door.  I've never quite made my peace, though, with the fact, that all that adorableness has, as its goal, the hoarding of large stockpiles of sugar. Over the years I've started buying only candy that I don't like (no Hershey's Special Darks — keep away from the Hershey's Special Darks), because that way I wouldn't be tempted by my own leftovers. And after a year or two of sucrose binges by the boys, I learned to have them dump their haul out on the kitchen table and measure out a subset of things they wanted to keep. The rest went to the hospital where my husband works, and were shared with children who were too sick to trick or treat. ( It's a counting game! And community service! And a lesson in self-control!)  I can't bring myself to become one of those people who hands out carrots and zucchinis or apples (not that most kids would be allowed to eat any of the above for fear of tampering). Bags of roasted nuts are out, for allergy reasons. So I give candy, and put aside, for a day, the thoughts of all the braces breaking and cavities forming and calories accumulating. But maybe a little less money spent on candy, while a chilling reminder of the economy, is not entirely bad news.
abstract: Maybe a little less money spent on candy, while a chilling reminder of the economy, is not entirely bad news.

headline.main: The Halloween Downturn
headline.print_headline: The Halloween Downturn

snippet: Judy Estrin, a serial technology entrepreneur, says in a new book that Silicon Valley — and the country — are facing a crisis of innovation.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED with clarification on Ms. Estrin's latest company  Judy Estrin, who has built several Silicon Valley companies and was the chief technology officer of Cisco Systems, says Silicon Valley is in trouble. In a new book, "Closing the Innovation Gap," which will be in bookstores Tuesday, she writes that the valley's problems are symptomatic of a crisis in innovation facing the country as a whole.   In an interview in her Menlo Park office Thursday, Ms. Estrin said that the United States is stifling innovation by failing to take risks in sectors from academia to government to venture capital. "I'm not generally an alarmist, but I am really, really concerned about this country," she said.   In her book, Ms. Estrin discusses everything from problems in elementary education to drug development, but her expertise is in information technology. Beginning in 1981, she co-founded three tech companies: Bridge Communications, Network Computing Devices and Precept Software. In 1998, Cisco acquired Precept and appointed her chief technology officer. She left in 2000 and co-founded Packet Design. She is now chief executive of JLABS.   Ms. Estrin traces Silicon Valley's troubles to the tech boom. She said that's when entrepreneurs and venture capitalists started focusing more on starting companies to turn around and sell them and less on building successful companies for the long term.   "Starting in 1998, there was such a shift in Silicon Valley toward chasing money and short-term returns," she said.   Part of the reason, she said, was that Cisco and other fast-growing big companies started acquiring start-ups with innovative technologies instead of developing new ideas internally. Entrepreneurs began founding companies with the goal of selling to a big tech company, and venture investors encouraged that.   Ms. Estrin acknowledged that innovative ideas still appear all over Silicon Valley. But, she said, the technologies at the root of new products like Apple's iPod or the Facebook social networking service were actually developed several decades ago. If entrepreneurs do not continue to develop groundbreaking technology, she said, the valley would be in dire straits in another decade. She compared the situation to a tree that appears to be growing well, but whose roots are rotting underground.   "In some ways, we have the problem that it looks like innovation is flourishing, but too much of it is short-term, incremental innovation," she said.   Since the tech bust, she said, venture investors have been too cautious. "What venture capitalists should do is start taking more risks again," she said. "Taking risks and failing is one of the most critical aspects of innovation."   The successes of her own career would not be possible in the current environment, she surmised. "The environment that was so rich and helped me start my career really is not there for my son," she said.
abstract: Judy Estrin, a serial technology entrepreneur, says in a new book that Silicon Valley — and the country — are facing a crisis of innovation.

headline.main: Does Silicon Valley Face an Innovation Crisis?
headline.print_headline: Does Silicon Valley Face an Innovation Crisis?

snippet: AOL is redesigning the home page of AOL.com once again, this time adding e-mail and social networking updates from rival services. What could AOL do to make this aging page relevant today?
lead_paragraph: Hey, Bits readers, I need your help: Does anyone out there use AOL.com (or the home screen of the AOL software) for anything? Why? And do you want any changes from it?   I'm asking this because I got a call late last week from Bill Wilson, the AOL executive vice president for programming, who wanted to talk about the latest improvements to AOL's portal. A decade ago this would have been a big deal. AOL's home screen was the town square of the Internet, and changes were closely watched.   Now, of course, AOL's Internet access service is a shell of its former self. And AOL.com mainly serves former AOL customers who still choose to keep their AOL e-mail addresses. But Mr. Wilson claims that the site still attracts 48 million people, so AOL has an incentive to keep them as engaged as possible and to try to attract more users.   I wonder whether AOL.com is like "The CBS Evening News" -- an icon from another age that serves an aging and declining audience, despite regular efforts at remodeling.   Mr. Wilson isn't ready to admit defeat, and he promises big changes.  "The portal model, although hugely successful for us and Yahoo and MSN, is an antiquated model," Mr. Wilson said. "What we really wanted to do was lean into the fragmentation of the Web and make AOL.com more open and relevant to users."   This sounds grand, but this year's batch of improvements, which will be added to the site over several weeks, are hardly revolutionary. To my mind, the most interesting aspect is how AOL offers to aggregate some services from other companies. The mail module now will display Yahoo Mail and Google's Gmail in addition to AOL's mail. And it will also soon bring together news feeds from Facebook, Twitter and MySpace as well as AOL's own Bebo social network.   There are a few other lightweight bits of personalization, like a display of local news for people who have entered their ZIP codes. And users can add their own links to the list of AOL sections on the navigation bar.   Curiously, there is a small module at the bottom of the page that can read RSS feeds. My instinct is that this is two orders of magnitude more geeky than the typical AOL customer would want. When I asked Mr. Wilson about this, he conceded that there is only a small group of core AOL users who may want an RSS reader. But that doesn't bother him.   "The play here is to attract a new audience," he said. "This is more a move to attract an audience that may be using another RSS reader to come here and stay because there is other value."   So I have one more question for Bits readers, who are much more interested in discussing Apple and Microsoft than AOL these days:   If you are the sort of person who would be interested in a site that would combine your e-mail, your social network updates and your RSS feeds, would you consider using it if the name was AOL.com?
abstract: AOL is redesigning the home page of AOL.com once again, this time adding e-mail and social networking updates from rival services. What could AOL do to make this aging page relevant today?

headline.main: Who Uses AOL and Why?
headline.print_headline: Who Uses AOL and Why?

snippet: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.
lead_paragraph: Amid the chaos on Wall Street Tuesday morning, another, much smaller bailout was announced: Best Buy is buying Napster, the second-place music subscription service, which has been losing money and subscribers.   The deal is almost a rounding error for a company of Best Buy's size. The stated price is $121 million. But since Napster has $67 million in cash, the effective cost to Best Buy is $54 million. That is still a good deal for Napster's shareholders because Best Buy will pay $2.65 a share, nearly double its closing price Friday.   Napster is a descendant of the Roxio music software company that bought the name and cat logo of the pioneering file sharing service that was started by Shawn Fanning and closed by the courts in 2001. Like other subscription services, it was an effort by the music industry to replicate the primary appeal of the original Napster: Listen to whatever you want whenever you want.   But the legal versions, as constructed by the music labels, have not caught on with listeners. The song downloads have digital rights management restrictions that limit what devices you can play them on. Moreover, they don't work at all on iPods, because Apple doesn't believe in subscription music.  Oh yes, they are all missing one crucial piece of the original Napster's appeal: Free. The subscription services, including the new Napster, cost about $15 a month.   Best Buy has long been interested in finding ways to sell services as well as products. It has offered a co-branded version of the Rhapsody, the leading music subscription service offered by Real Networks.   In its announcement, it is significant that Best Buy hardly mentioned music subscription. Rather, it described the company's emerging capabilities to offer services through cellphones, its technology and customer service operations. The company said it was keeping Napster's management and its Los Angeles operation.   "We can foresee Napster acting as a platform for accelerating our growth in the emerging industry of digital entertainment, beyond music subscriptions," said Dave Morrish, Best Buy's executive vice president for connected digital solutions, in the company's news release.   I think the jury is out about how much retailers can profit from selling services. There is some money to be made bundling services with phones and other devices, just as personal computer makers earn something from changing the search defaults and installing trial software on their machines. But there is also a backlash from customers who don't like the clutter of all these add-ons.   I also wonder whether consumers may be less open to house brands for services than for products. You may well buy a no-name DVD player or LCD TV if it has the features you want at a price you like. But a service is a promise of continued commitment to innovation and customer care. It may be that customers will prefer well-known brands for them.   Of course, Best Buy, which has done a good job establishing its Geek Squad brand of tech support, might be able to turn Napster into a national brand of media services. But there is just as much of a chance that the acquisition will dissolve into the retail giant, and the Napster cat will die for good this time.
abstract: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.

headline.main: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster
headline.print_headline: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster

lead_paragraph: Diptyque is an avant-garde, resolutely chic Parisian scent concern whose perfumes and candles push boundaries, take risks and generally form one of the most interesting collections in the world. Their brilliant Philosykos, created in 1996 for Diptyque by Olivia Giacobetti, is often credited with the late 1990s fig craze. Eau de Lierre is mesmerizing, Olene is wonderfully strange and L’Ombre dans l’Eau is not merely strange but bracingly rebarbative. Against the flood of focus-grouped syrup, the house has resolutely charted noncommercial, inaccessible territory and done it brilliantly. This is why the choice of its latest triptych of launches at first seems odd.

snippet: Glassdoor.com rates the best and worst chief executives of the year, based on anonymous employee reviews. The top boss: Arthur Levinson of Genentech. The worst: Steve Odland of Office Depot.
lead_paragraph: Glassdoor.com, a site that lets employees anonymously review their employers and share salary information, is out with a list of the naughtiest and nicest chief executives of 2008, based on those reviews.  (Photo: Arthur Levinson, chief of Genentech. (Credit: Kimberly White/Reuters)) The nicest boss of all was Arthur D. Levinson, chief of Genentech, who got a 93 percent approval rating. He leads the Silicon Valley biotech company with a "decision-making structure that intrinsically forces authority downward to the lowest possible level providing many opportunities to exercise and test one's judgment," a strategic planner at Genentech wrote.   Overall, 6 of the top 10 bosses on the "nice" list were from Silicon Valley, including Steve Jobs of Apple, with a 90 percent approval rating; Eric E. Schmidt of Google, with 88 percent; Jen-Hsun Huang of Nvidia, with 80 percent; Shantanu Narayen of Adobe, with 79 percent; and Dan Warmenhoven of NetApp, with 78 percent.  Despite a lousy year for financial firms, two Wall Street bosses made the "nice" list, including Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, with an 88 percent approval rating, and Kenneth Chenault of American Express, with 80 percent approval. A.G. Lafley of Procter & Gamble and Ian Davis of McKinsey rounded out the top 10.   The worst chief executive of the year was Steve Odland of Office Depot, according to Glassdoor.com's reviewers. He had an 80 percent disapproval rating. "Fire Odland," wrote a department manager. "The corporate office in Delray Beach, FL is asleep at the wheel and frankly incompetent. Maybe if some of them would listen to or maybe even spend a few hours in a store they would understand their own business a little better."   Anthony LaFetra, chief of Rain Bird, an irrigation company, was second-worst, with a 75 percent disapproval rating. "Your employees, both short and long term, are voting with their feet and exiting in a steady stream," wrote one employee in an open memo to management. "In what delusional alternate universe do you exist where this level of turnover and loss of legacy knowledge is good for any company?"   But tech companies dominated the bad-boss list, taking seven of the remaining spots in the top 10 -- hardly a badge of honor for an industry that likes to boast about its great workplace culture.   Randy Falco of AOL received a 68 percent disapproval rating, and Greg Brown of Motorola and Ron Rittenmeyer of EDS (now part of Hewlett-Packard) were close behind. Kevin W. Sharer of Amgen, Lynn R. Blodgett of Affiliated Computer Services, Jonathan Schwartz of Sun Microsystems and John Donahoe, who replaced Meg Whitman this year as the head of eBay, also made the list.   Rounding out the hall of shame was James R. Pouliot of CSAA Inter-Insurance Bureau.  Glassdoor.com went live in June 2008. It was founded and initially financed by Robert Hohman, Tim Besse and Rich Barton, all of whom came from Expedia, which Mr. Barton started. Since then, Benchmark Capital, where Mr. Barton is a venture partner, led a $3 million round of financing and Sutter Hill Ventures led a $6.5 million round.
abstract: Glassdoor.com rates the best and worst chief executives of the year, based on anonymous employee reviews. The top boss: Arthur Levinson of Genentech. The worst: Steve Odland of Office Depot.

headline.main: Naughtiest and Nicest C.E.O.’s
headline.print_headline: Glassdoor.com Lists Naughtiest and Nicest C.E.O.'s of 2008

snippet: White House aides were said to be grumbling about a tradition that looks as if it rarely existed.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Presidents No. 43 and 44 at the White House on Monday. (Photo by Mark Wilson/Getty Images)) There was somewhat of a stir Tuesday from anonymous White House aides who were said to be angry with aides to President-elect Barack Obama for leaking details of his meeting with President Bush at the White House on Monday. The aides, who were quoted in the Drudge Report, cited a "long-standing tradition" of keeping mum about sit-downs between incoming and outgoing presidents.  Any grumbling assumes there were real "leaks" from Obama insiders. But beyond that, is there such a tradition of presidential omerta?   A check of newspaper clippings finds that if it ever existed, it has been broken frequently before.  For instance, after incoming President Bill Clinton met with outgoing President George H.W. Bush 16 years ago, both sides shared some of the details.  From The New York Times then:    According to accounts provided by both Mr. Clinton and by the White House, the discussion focused more on Mr. Bush's favorite subject, foreign affairs, than on Mr. Clinton's preferred turf, domestic concerns.   And when incoming President George W. Bush met with outgoing President Clinton eight years ago, Mr. Clinton did some of the briefing, himself.  From The New York Times then:   Dealing with North Korea, a topic that came up at length in the later private meeting along with Russia, China and the Middle East, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "When I had this meeting eight years ago with the president-elect's father, he told me that the biggest problem we were facing was the nuclear program in North Korea, and we were able to build on the work they had done and put an end to that. And now the big problem there is the missile program. We may have a chance to put an end to that, and if we can, I think we should."   The meeting between President-elect Ronald Reagan and outgoing President Jimmy Carter was a less newsy affair, though tensions did break out between Nancy Reagan and Rosalynn Carter afterward.   From The New York Times a couple of weeks later in 1980:    Nancy Reagan has apparently patched things up with Rosalynn Carter. According to Mrs. Carter, Mrs. Reagan telephoned on Sunday to deny that she had ever expressed a desire that the Carters move out of the White House early so it could be redecorated in time for the Reagans's arrival on Jan. 20.  Mrs. Carter, who disclosed the phone call yesterday while showing reporters the White House Christmas tree, said she had assured Mrs. Reagan that she had not been bothered about the alleged remarks.     News even leaked out from the second White House meeting between outgoing President Lyndon B. Johnson and incoming President-elect Richard M. Nixon in 1968 (the first meeting was less newsy.)   From The New York Times following their second meeting in December of 1968, under the byline of R.W. Apple Jr.:   One question touched upon, according to qualified sources, was whether the Johnson administration should begin negotiations with the Soviet Union on the limitation of nuclear missiles before it leaves office in 38 days.
abstract: White House aides were said to be grumbling about a tradition that looks as if it rarely existed.

headline.main: Did Leakers Break a Transition Tradition?
headline.print_headline: Did Leakers Break a Transition Tradition?

snippet: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.
lead_paragraph: Amid the chaos on Wall Street Tuesday morning, another, much smaller bailout was announced: Best Buy is buying Napster, the second-place music subscription service, which has been losing money and subscribers.   The deal is almost a rounding error for a company of Best Buy's size. The stated price is $121 million. But since Napster has $67 million in cash, the effective cost to Best Buy is $54 million. That is still a good deal for Napster's shareholders because Best Buy will pay $2.65 a share, nearly double its closing price Friday.   Napster is a descendant of the Roxio music software company that bought the name and cat logo of the pioneering file sharing service that was started by Shawn Fanning and closed by the courts in 2001. Like other subscription services, it was an effort by the music industry to replicate the primary appeal of the original Napster: Listen to whatever you want whenever you want.   But the legal versions, as constructed by the music labels, have not caught on with listeners. The song downloads have digital rights management restrictions that limit what devices you can play them on. Moreover, they don't work at all on iPods, because Apple doesn't believe in subscription music.  Oh yes, they are all missing one crucial piece of the original Napster's appeal: Free. The subscription services, including the new Napster, cost about $15 a month.   Best Buy has long been interested in finding ways to sell services as well as products. It has offered a co-branded version of the Rhapsody, the leading music subscription service offered by Real Networks.   In its announcement, it is significant that Best Buy hardly mentioned music subscription. Rather, it described the company's emerging capabilities to offer services through cellphones, its technology and customer service operations. The company said it was keeping Napster's management and its Los Angeles operation.   "We can foresee Napster acting as a platform for accelerating our growth in the emerging industry of digital entertainment, beyond music subscriptions," said Dave Morrish, Best Buy's executive vice president for connected digital solutions, in the company's news release.   I think the jury is out about how much retailers can profit from selling services. There is some money to be made bundling services with phones and other devices, just as personal computer makers earn something from changing the search defaults and installing trial software on their machines. But there is also a backlash from customers who don't like the clutter of all these add-ons.   I also wonder whether consumers may be less open to house brands for services than for products. You may well buy a no-name DVD player or LCD TV if it has the features you want at a price you like. But a service is a promise of continued commitment to innovation and customer care. It may be that customers will prefer well-known brands for them.   Of course, Best Buy, which has done a good job establishing its Geek Squad brand of tech support, might be able to turn Napster into a national brand of media services. But there is just as much of a chance that the acquisition will dissolve into the retail giant, and the Napster cat will die for good this time.
abstract: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.

headline.main: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster
headline.print_headline: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster

snippet: Glassdoor.com rates the best and worst chief executives of the year, based on anonymous employee reviews. The top boss: Arthur Levinson of Genentech. The worst: Steve Odland of Office Depot.
lead_paragraph: Glassdoor.com, a site that lets employees anonymously review their employers and share salary information, is out with a list of the naughtiest and nicest chief executives of 2008, based on those reviews.  (Photo: Arthur Levinson, chief of Genentech. (Credit: Kimberly White/Reuters)) The nicest boss of all was Arthur D. Levinson, chief of Genentech, who got a 93 percent approval rating. He leads the Silicon Valley biotech company with a "decision-making structure that intrinsically forces authority downward to the lowest possible level providing many opportunities to exercise and test one's judgment," a strategic planner at Genentech wrote.   Overall, 6 of the top 10 bosses on the "nice" list were from Silicon Valley, including Steve Jobs of Apple, with a 90 percent approval rating; Eric E. Schmidt of Google, with 88 percent; Jen-Hsun Huang of Nvidia, with 80 percent; Shantanu Narayen of Adobe, with 79 percent; and Dan Warmenhoven of NetApp, with 78 percent.  Despite a lousy year for financial firms, two Wall Street bosses made the "nice" list, including Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, with an 88 percent approval rating, and Kenneth Chenault of American Express, with 80 percent approval. A.G. Lafley of Procter & Gamble and Ian Davis of McKinsey rounded out the top 10.   The worst chief executive of the year was Steve Odland of Office Depot, according to Glassdoor.com's reviewers. He had an 80 percent disapproval rating. "Fire Odland," wrote a department manager. "The corporate office in Delray Beach, FL is asleep at the wheel and frankly incompetent. Maybe if some of them would listen to or maybe even spend a few hours in a store they would understand their own business a little better."   Anthony LaFetra, chief of Rain Bird, an irrigation company, was second-worst, with a 75 percent disapproval rating. "Your employees, both short and long term, are voting with their feet and exiting in a steady stream," wrote one employee in an open memo to management. "In what delusional alternate universe do you exist where this level of turnover and loss of legacy knowledge is good for any company?"   But tech companies dominated the bad-boss list, taking seven of the remaining spots in the top 10 -- hardly a badge of honor for an industry that likes to boast about its great workplace culture.   Randy Falco of AOL received a 68 percent disapproval rating, and Greg Brown of Motorola and Ron Rittenmeyer of EDS (now part of Hewlett-Packard) were close behind. Kevin W. Sharer of Amgen, Lynn R. Blodgett of Affiliated Computer Services, Jonathan Schwartz of Sun Microsystems and John Donahoe, who replaced Meg Whitman this year as the head of eBay, also made the list.   Rounding out the hall of shame was James R. Pouliot of CSAA Inter-Insurance Bureau.  Glassdoor.com went live in June 2008. It was founded and initially financed by Robert Hohman, Tim Besse and Rich Barton, all of whom came from Expedia, which Mr. Barton started. Since then, Benchmark Capital, where Mr. Barton is a venture partner, led a $3 million round of financing and Sutter Hill Ventures led a $6.5 million round.
abstract: Glassdoor.com rates the best and worst chief executives of the year, based on anonymous employee reviews. The top boss: Arthur Levinson of Genentech. The worst: Steve Odland of Office Depot.

headline.main: Naughtiest and Nicest C.E.O.’s
headline.print_headline: Glassdoor.com Lists Naughtiest and Nicest C.E.O.'s of 2008

snippet: White House aides were said to be grumbling about a tradition that looks as if it rarely existed.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Presidents No. 43 and 44 at the White House on Monday. (Photo by Mark Wilson/Getty Images)) There was somewhat of a stir Tuesday from anonymous White House aides who were said to be angry with aides to President-elect Barack Obama for leaking details of his meeting with President Bush at the White House on Monday. The aides, who were quoted in the Drudge Report, cited a "long-standing tradition" of keeping mum about sit-downs between incoming and outgoing presidents.  Any grumbling assumes there were real "leaks" from Obama insiders. But beyond that, is there such a tradition of presidential omerta?   A check of newspaper clippings finds that if it ever existed, it has been broken frequently before.  For instance, after incoming President Bill Clinton met with outgoing President George H.W. Bush 16 years ago, both sides shared some of the details.  From The New York Times then:    According to accounts provided by both Mr. Clinton and by the White House, the discussion focused more on Mr. Bush's favorite subject, foreign affairs, than on Mr. Clinton's preferred turf, domestic concerns.   And when incoming President George W. Bush met with outgoing President Clinton eight years ago, Mr. Clinton did some of the briefing, himself.  From The New York Times then:   Dealing with North Korea, a topic that came up at length in the later private meeting along with Russia, China and the Middle East, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "When I had this meeting eight years ago with the president-elect's father, he told me that the biggest problem we were facing was the nuclear program in North Korea, and we were able to build on the work they had done and put an end to that. And now the big problem there is the missile program. We may have a chance to put an end to that, and if we can, I think we should."   The meeting between President-elect Ronald Reagan and outgoing President Jimmy Carter was a less newsy affair, though tensions did break out between Nancy Reagan and Rosalynn Carter afterward.   From The New York Times a couple of weeks later in 1980:    Nancy Reagan has apparently patched things up with Rosalynn Carter. According to Mrs. Carter, Mrs. Reagan telephoned on Sunday to deny that she had ever expressed a desire that the Carters move out of the White House early so it could be redecorated in time for the Reagans's arrival on Jan. 20.  Mrs. Carter, who disclosed the phone call yesterday while showing reporters the White House Christmas tree, said she had assured Mrs. Reagan that she had not been bothered about the alleged remarks.     News even leaked out from the second White House meeting between outgoing President Lyndon B. Johnson and incoming President-elect Richard M. Nixon in 1968 (the first meeting was less newsy.)   From The New York Times following their second meeting in December of 1968, under the byline of R.W. Apple Jr.:   One question touched upon, according to qualified sources, was whether the Johnson administration should begin negotiations with the Soviet Union on the limitation of nuclear missiles before it leaves office in 38 days.
abstract: White House aides were said to be grumbling about a tradition that looks as if it rarely existed.

headline.main: Did Leakers Break a Transition Tradition?
headline.print_headline: Did Leakers Break a Transition Tradition?

snippet: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.
lead_paragraph: Amid the chaos on Wall Street Tuesday morning, another, much smaller bailout was announced: Best Buy is buying Napster, the second-place music subscription service, which has been losing money and subscribers.   The deal is almost a rounding error for a company of Best Buy's size. The stated price is $121 million. But since Napster has $67 million in cash, the effective cost to Best Buy is $54 million. That is still a good deal for Napster's shareholders because Best Buy will pay $2.65 a share, nearly double its closing price Friday.   Napster is a descendant of the Roxio music software company that bought the name and cat logo of the pioneering file sharing service that was started by Shawn Fanning and closed by the courts in 2001. Like other subscription services, it was an effort by the music industry to replicate the primary appeal of the original Napster: Listen to whatever you want whenever you want.   But the legal versions, as constructed by the music labels, have not caught on with listeners. The song downloads have digital rights management restrictions that limit what devices you can play them on. Moreover, they don't work at all on iPods, because Apple doesn't believe in subscription music.  Oh yes, they are all missing one crucial piece of the original Napster's appeal: Free. The subscription services, including the new Napster, cost about $15 a month.   Best Buy has long been interested in finding ways to sell services as well as products. It has offered a co-branded version of the Rhapsody, the leading music subscription service offered by Real Networks.   In its announcement, it is significant that Best Buy hardly mentioned music subscription. Rather, it described the company's emerging capabilities to offer services through cellphones, its technology and customer service operations. The company said it was keeping Napster's management and its Los Angeles operation.   "We can foresee Napster acting as a platform for accelerating our growth in the emerging industry of digital entertainment, beyond music subscriptions," said Dave Morrish, Best Buy's executive vice president for connected digital solutions, in the company's news release.   I think the jury is out about how much retailers can profit from selling services. There is some money to be made bundling services with phones and other devices, just as personal computer makers earn something from changing the search defaults and installing trial software on their machines. But there is also a backlash from customers who don't like the clutter of all these add-ons.   I also wonder whether consumers may be less open to house brands for services than for products. You may well buy a no-name DVD player or LCD TV if it has the features you want at a price you like. But a service is a promise of continued commitment to innovation and customer care. It may be that customers will prefer well-known brands for them.   Of course, Best Buy, which has done a good job establishing its Geek Squad brand of tech support, might be able to turn Napster into a national brand of media services. But there is just as much of a chance that the acquisition will dissolve into the retail giant, and the Napster cat will die for good this time.
abstract: Napster is set to be acquired by Best Buy. But the retail giant wants Napster’s technology and nascent mobile phone business more than its main music service.

headline.main: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster
headline.print_headline: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster

lead_paragraph: Diptyque is an avant-garde, resolutely chic Parisian scent concern whose perfumes and candles push boundaries, take risks and generally form one of the most interesting collections in the world. Their brilliant Philosykos, created in 1996 for Diptyque by Olivia Giacobetti, is often credited with the late 1990s fig craze. Eau de Lierre is mesmerizing, Olene is wonderfully strange and L’Ombre dans l’Eau is not merely strange but bracingly rebarbative. Against the flood of focus-grouped syrup, the house has resolutely charted noncommercial, inaccessible territory and done it brilliantly. This is why the choice of its latest triptych of launches at first seems odd.

snippet: Bringing back a milk pudding — and then rebelling against it.
lead_paragraph: People in the 19th century had a more robust appetite for food with unusual textures. Pickled oysters were a common snack, and you could find the occasional brain fritter and kidney omelet. But nothing seems to have got cooks more excited than a chance to entomb a favorite food in jelly. Into a preserve went perfectly innocent ham, pineapple, calf’s foot, sole, even a chicken or two. And then there was milk. Sweetened with sugar, lemon, almond, cinnamon and sometimes even chocolate, milk was ideal for pouring into molds and serving for dessert as a beloved dish called blancmange, which means “white food.” Tapped out of its form, blancmange is gorgeous and subdued, like a piece of carved ivory.
abstract: Bringing back a milk pudding — and then rebelling against it.

snippet: Hannah Emily Upp, a 23-year-old Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago, was found safe in the upper waters of New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Hannah E. Upp, 23, was in stable condition at a hospital on Staten Island. ) Updated, 6:11 p.m. | Deckhands for a Staten Island ferry boat rescued a woman from the waters of New York's Upper Bay on Tuesday and officials later said she was 23-year-old Hannah Emily Upp, a Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago.  Ms. Upp was plucked from the swells, taken to shore and immediately transported to Richmond University Medical Center, on Staten Island, where officials said she was in stable condition.  "Detectives positively identified her as Hannah Upp," said Paul J. Browne, the Police Department's chief spokesman.   The rescue, which unfolded shortly before noon on a warm September day, capped a saga that began when Ms. Upp disappeared on Aug. 29, the Friday before the start of the school year.  Ms. Upp is a New York City teaching fellow set to begin her second year as a Spanish instructor at the Thurgood Marshall Middle School in Harlem. Her disappearance baffled her relatives and friends, touched off a citywide search and prompted the teachers' union to offer a $10,000 reward for information (in addition to a $2,000 award from the Crime Stoppers program). Friends of Ms. Upp even set up a Facebook page, called "We're Not Giving Upp (on Hannah)," seeking information.   After she vanished, investigators found Ms. Upp's apartment in Hamilton Heights full of her belongings, including her keys, credit cards, wallet, cellphone and a passport. She is believed to have last withdrawn money from her bank account a day earlier.  "It was as though she had left without taking any the things people normally would have with them," Mr. Browne said.  Investigators searched Ms. Upp's building and contacted every tenant. They searched the brush in the overgrown backyard as well as a nearby park, "to make sure she was not the victim of some foul play," Mr. Browne said. "We checked all the phone calls on that cellphone."  The police also posted fliers emblazoned with Ms. Upp's photograph.   But then -- just as mysteriously as she vanished -- Ms. Upp showed up.  Ms. Upp was seen checking her e-mail in an Apple store at Fifth Avenue and East 59th Street in Manhattan, the police said.  On a Friday evening, a classmate of Ms. Upp's at Pace University saw her in the Apple store and approached her, but she appeared to avoid him and, the police said, disappeared again. Investigators subsequently learned that someone had accessed Ms. Upp's laptop from that store, and then the police uncovered videotape from a store surveillance camera that confirmed Ms. Upp had been there. The police had her family view the videotape to try to confirm that the film showed her.  The police determined that Ms. Upp had been in the store twice within four days, and investigators began to look through her laptop to try to determine her contacts.  Things were somewhat quiet until Tuesday morning.  Then, a pilot of the ferry boat known as the John J. Marchi -- one in the fleet of commuter ferries run by the city's Department of Transportation -- saw a woman in the water as it approached the Staten Island terminal from Manhattan, officials said.  Mr. Browne said investigators believed the woman -- later identified as Ms. Upp -- had jumped from the pier into the water.     The pilot of the ferry had some deckhands launch a small rescue craft and steer it toward the woman, said Scott Gastel, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation. "The rescue boat was lowered from the Marchi," Mr. Gastel said.   Michael J. Sabatino, who was operating the rescue boat -- a 12-foot skiff with an outboard motor -- saw Ms. Upp, slowed the boat and grabbed her by the ankle as his partner took hold of her shoulders and back.  "She was floating face down in the water, just like lifeless," said Mr. Sabatino, 28. "She gasped desperately for air and she laid down and started crying when we got her in the boat. She had a slight shaking."  He added: "I tapped her lightly to make sure she was somewhat conscious and that she could open her eyes and so we could see that she was breathing, otherwise we would have had to do medical treatment on the boat. We had no words out of her; we had no idea who she was; we just rushed her back to land."   When the ferry workers got to Ms. Upp's side, she was close to drowning and did not say anything, said Seth Solomonow, a spokesman for the transportation department. "She was almost completely incapacitated when they pulled her out," said Mr. Solomonow. "She was not responsive."  Ms. Upp was dressed in the same clothes she was said to be wearing when she went missing: a red tank top, black shorts and sneakers.   Janette Sadik-Khan, the city's transportation commissioner, said in a statement, "The safety of passengers is the top priority for our staff at the Staten Island Ferry. Today's rescue is something that every Staten Island ferry crew member trains for, but hopes they will never actually perform. I commend the ferry crew for their heroic efforts."  The Transportation Department elaborated with some additional information:     The 11:30 a.m. ferry Senator John J. Marchi was en route from Manhattan about one mile from St. George Terminal on Staten Island when Capt. Chris Covella saw a figure in the water, on the right, New Jersey side of the boat. After confirming with binoculars that this was a person in the water, Captain Covella set a course for the person and alerted the crew to rescue stations. A rescue launch aboard #1 Rescue Boat (which was lowered from the Marchi), staffed by deckhands Michael Sabatino and Ephriam Washington, recovered a woman, found floating facedown, from the water. She did take a gasp and made some noise, but was otherwise unresponsive. The rescue boat went straight to shore with the woman. The total time from Capt. Covella's sighting the woman and docking at St. George was eight minutes. FDNY and EMS personnel handled it from that point. The rescue was the second for Deckhand Sabatino, who was in the rescue boat that plucked a man from the water in August 2007. Several Marine Oilers and Marine Engineers on the Marchi were involved in getting the Marchi to St. George in a safe and timely manner.   Prior to her rescue, the police were closing in on Ms. Upp. She had been seen at a Dunkin Donuts in Staten Island. Officers went there, saw a commotion at the nearby ferry terminal and – on a hunch – followed the action to the hospital. But she declined to speak to detectives, Mr. Browne said.  He said that in tracing Ms. Upp's movements, investigators found that she had visited eight different locations of New York Sports Club in the first week she was missing, "to take showers." She used her own name and explained she had lost her club I.D., said Mr. Browne, but then apparently stopped visiting the clubs.   Hannah Wood, a friend of Ms. Upp's, said on Tuesday that she believed Ms. Upp's mother would be at her daughter's side. But she declined to comment further.   When the rescue occurred, the ferry boat was about a mile from docking at the pier at St. George, officials said.
abstract: Hannah Emily Upp, a 23-year-old Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago, was found safe in the upper waters of New York Harbor.

headline.main: Ferry Workers Rescue Missing Teacher
headline.print_headline: Ferry Workers Rescue Missing Teacher
