snippet: Oracle has teamed with Hewlett-Packard, rather than traditional partners Sun and Dell, on new data warehousing hardware.
lead_paragraph: Oracle dealt a blow Wednesday to its longtime ally Sun Microsystems by "entering the hardware business" in tandem with Hewlett-Packard.   Oracle, best known for its database software and related applications, showed off a pair of new server systems that should make its database run faster than ever before and give the company a leg up in the growing field for systems known as data warehouses.   "That's right, Oracle is going into the hardware business. But we're not going alone," said Oracle's chief executive, Larry Ellison, speaking at the company's user conference in San Francisco.   Oracle, in fact, is not entering the hardware business in any traditional sense. Salespeople working for the software company can take orders for the new systems, but H.P. will make, deliver and service the gear –- just as it has always done.   The major difference with this partnership involves Oracle's decision to champion H.P. over its other close hardware partners like Sun and Dell. In the past, Oracle may very well have struck a deal like this with Sun, as Mr. Ellison has long counted Sun's chairman, Scott McNealy, as both a personal friend and strong business ally.   Times have changed, however with H.P.'s server business growing while Sun's declines. In addition, Sun acquired MySQL, a maker of open source database software that competes with Oracle.   As far as the hardware goes, Oracle will plant its database on an H.P. server that has vast amounts of storage. By placing lots of storage close to the processors inside the server, Oracle can bolster the performance of its database software, since requests for information no longer have to travel out to external storage systems over a network.  H.P. is then combining a number of these base systems with more of its regular servers to form something Oracle is calling a Database Machine.   "We are not talking the iPod Nano here," Mr. Ellison said. "This is 1,400 times larger than Apple's largest iPod. Even your peer-to-peer network will have a hard time filling this thing up."  Rather than having anything to do with music, the Database Machine is aimed at data warehousing jobs. This technology helps customers such as retailers and manufactures keep track of all their inventory, sales and other business data, and it lets them search and sort this data in sophisticated ways with the hopes of learning more about the state of a company's business.   A number of start-ups, along with Microsoft and I.B.M., also compete in the data warehouse market.   Wednesday's announcement appears to be more about branding than creating something new. The H.P. hardware being used by Oracle is very much standard gear. Any customer could assemble a Database Machine on its own.   And H.P. has its own line of data warehouse systems called NeoView. It's a natural play for H.P., since its chief executive, Mark Hurd, once captained Teradata, the leading data warehouse software maker, before taking over as the H.P. boss.   Mr. Ellison largely ignored the rest of Oracle's product line during his OpenWorld speech.   "It's weird for a software company to say hardware is the answer to the problem and not go into the software side at all," said China Martens, a software analyst at The 451 Group.
abstract: Oracle has teamed with Hewlett-Packard, rather than traditional partners Sun and Dell, on new data warehousing hardware.

headline.main: Oracle Embraces H.P. in 'Hardware' Push

snippet: A collection of linked stories centers on a rural town and the depraved misfits who live there.
lead_paragraph: The only display of civic pride evident in Donald Ray Pollock’s first book is a blue tattoo  the words “Knockemstiff, Ohio”  etched “like a road sign” on the bony white backside of a crackhead named Sandy. And even that’s suspect, since the tattoo seems less a proud-spirited nod to her hometown than a dog-tag-like reminder of where she needs to return, or be returned. Located 60-some miles south of Columbus, Knockemstiff, which derives its name from a long-ago fight between two women, is a ramshackle cluster of “shotgun houses and rust-streaked trailers” where the air is suffused with rotten-egg-scented smog from the local paper mill. Once there was a store, selling gasoline and Doan’s liver pills and cigarettes and chain-saw oil, and also a tavern, Hap’s, where the bartender dealt speed on the side. A baseball diamond, built by a Vista worker in the ’60s, then swiftly reclaimed by green briars, and also a church  but that too, as Sandy’s boyfriend notes, “had fallen on hard times.” It’s a mean little place, in Pollock’s rendering, where the dominant occupation seems to be petty crime, where wife-beating louts drink Old Grand-Dad out of car ashtrays and where restless teenage boys spend their weekend nights throwing darts at the fat kid and compensating him with bong hits.
abstract: A collection of linked stories centers on a rural town and the depraved misfits who live there.

snippet: Hannah Emily Upp, a 23-year-old Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago, was found safe in the upper waters of New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Hannah E. Upp, 23, was in stable condition at a hospital on Staten Island. ) Updated, 6:11 p.m. | Deckhands for a Staten Island ferry boat rescued a woman from the waters of New York's Upper Bay on Tuesday and officials later said she was 23-year-old Hannah Emily Upp, a Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago.  Ms. Upp was plucked from the swells, taken to shore and immediately transported to Richmond University Medical Center, on Staten Island, where officials said she was in stable condition.  "Detectives positively identified her as Hannah Upp," said Paul J. Browne, the Police Department's chief spokesman.   The rescue, which unfolded shortly before noon on a warm September day, capped a saga that began when Ms. Upp disappeared on Aug. 29, the Friday before the start of the school year.  Ms. Upp is a New York City teaching fellow set to begin her second year as a Spanish instructor at the Thurgood Marshall Middle School in Harlem. Her disappearance baffled her relatives and friends, touched off a citywide search and prompted the teachers' union to offer a $10,000 reward for information (in addition to a $2,000 award from the Crime Stoppers program). Friends of Ms. Upp even set up a Facebook page, called "We're Not Giving Upp (on Hannah)," seeking information.   After she vanished, investigators found Ms. Upp's apartment in Hamilton Heights full of her belongings, including her keys, credit cards, wallet, cellphone and a passport. She is believed to have last withdrawn money from her bank account a day earlier.  "It was as though she had left without taking any the things people normally would have with them," Mr. Browne said.  Investigators searched Ms. Upp's building and contacted every tenant. They searched the brush in the overgrown backyard as well as a nearby park, "to make sure she was not the victim of some foul play," Mr. Browne said. "We checked all the phone calls on that cellphone."  The police also posted fliers emblazoned with Ms. Upp's photograph.   But then -- just as mysteriously as she vanished -- Ms. Upp showed up.  Ms. Upp was seen checking her e-mail in an Apple store at Fifth Avenue and East 59th Street in Manhattan, the police said.  On a Friday evening, a classmate of Ms. Upp's at Pace University saw her in the Apple store and approached her, but she appeared to avoid him and, the police said, disappeared again. Investigators subsequently learned that someone had accessed Ms. Upp's laptop from that store, and then the police uncovered videotape from a store surveillance camera that confirmed Ms. Upp had been there. The police had her family view the videotape to try to confirm that the film showed her.  The police determined that Ms. Upp had been in the store twice within four days, and investigators began to look through her laptop to try to determine her contacts.  Things were somewhat quiet until Tuesday morning.  Then, a pilot of the ferry boat known as the John J. Marchi -- one in the fleet of commuter ferries run by the city's Department of Transportation -- saw a woman in the water as it approached the Staten Island terminal from Manhattan, officials said.  Mr. Browne said investigators believed the woman -- later identified as Ms. Upp -- had jumped from the pier into the water.     The pilot of the ferry had some deckhands launch a small rescue craft and steer it toward the woman, said Scott Gastel, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation. "The rescue boat was lowered from the Marchi," Mr. Gastel said.   Michael J. Sabatino, who was operating the rescue boat -- a 12-foot skiff with an outboard motor -- saw Ms. Upp, slowed the boat and grabbed her by the ankle as his partner took hold of her shoulders and back.  "She was floating face down in the water, just like lifeless," said Mr. Sabatino, 28. "She gasped desperately for air and she laid down and started crying when we got her in the boat. She had a slight shaking."  He added: "I tapped her lightly to make sure she was somewhat conscious and that she could open her eyes and so we could see that she was breathing, otherwise we would have had to do medical treatment on the boat. We had no words out of her; we had no idea who she was; we just rushed her back to land."   When the ferry workers got to Ms. Upp's side, she was close to drowning and did not say anything, said Seth Solomonow, a spokesman for the transportation department. "She was almost completely incapacitated when they pulled her out," said Mr. Solomonow. "She was not responsive."  Ms. Upp was dressed in the same clothes she was said to be wearing when she went missing: a red tank top, black shorts and sneakers.   Janette Sadik-Khan, the city's transportation commissioner, said in a statement, "The safety of passengers is the top priority for our staff at the Staten Island Ferry. Today's rescue is something that every Staten Island ferry crew member trains for, but hopes they will never actually perform. I commend the ferry crew for their heroic efforts."  The Transportation Department elaborated with some additional information:     The 11:30 a.m. ferry Senator John J. Marchi was en route from Manhattan about one mile from St. George Terminal on Staten Island when Capt. Chris Covella saw a figure in the water, on the right, New Jersey side of the boat. After confirming with binoculars that this was a person in the water, Captain Covella set a course for the person and alerted the crew to rescue stations. A rescue launch aboard #1 Rescue Boat (which was lowered from the Marchi), staffed by deckhands Michael Sabatino and Ephriam Washington, recovered a woman, found floating facedown, from the water. She did take a gasp and made some noise, but was otherwise unresponsive. The rescue boat went straight to shore with the woman. The total time from Capt. Covella's sighting the woman and docking at St. George was eight minutes. FDNY and EMS personnel handled it from that point. The rescue was the second for Deckhand Sabatino, who was in the rescue boat that plucked a man from the water in August 2007. Several Marine Oilers and Marine Engineers on the Marchi were involved in getting the Marchi to St. George in a safe and timely manner.   Prior to her rescue, the police were closing in on Ms. Upp. She had been seen at a Dunkin Donuts in Staten Island. Officers went there, saw a commotion at the nearby ferry terminal and – on a hunch – followed the action to the hospital. But she declined to speak to detectives, Mr. Browne said.  He said that in tracing Ms. Upp's movements, investigators found that she had visited eight different locations of New York Sports Club in the first week she was missing, "to take showers." She used her own name and explained she had lost her club I.D., said Mr. Browne, but then apparently stopped visiting the clubs.   Hannah Wood, a friend of Ms. Upp's, said on Tuesday that she believed Ms. Upp's mother would be at her daughter's side. But she declined to comment further.   When the rescue occurred, the ferry boat was about a mile from docking at the pier at St. George, officials said.
abstract: Hannah Emily Upp, a 23-year-old Manhattan teacher who disappeared more than two weeks ago, was found safe in the upper waters of New York Harbor.

snippet: A Seattle firm has created a new site, ObamaCTO.org, for people to funnel tech policy ideas to the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Barack Obama's presence on Facebook. (Credit: Peter Wynn Thompson for The New York Times)) Tech geeks are tickled that come January, one of their kind will be in the White House. With the election of Barack Obama, a text-messaging Facebook user who has promised to hire the nation's first chief technology officer, Silicon Valley has a newfound interest in the inner workings of Washington.   Who should get the role of C.T.O. -- the geeks' representative in Washington -- has been the subject of intense debate in the tech community. On Tuesday, a few of those geeks started ObamaCTO.org, a Web site with advice for the C.T.O., whomever he or she might be. (Obama has said he planned to get ideas directly from voters, and he is already doing so at his transition Web site, Change.gov.)   Obama CTO was built by Front Seat, a small Seattle software company that creates Web sites for civic causes. Its biggest project is Walk Score, a site that ranks neighborhoods by how walkable they are. They got the idea to build Obama CTO around noon on Tuesday and posted it by the afternoon.   The idea came, oddly enough, from the Republicans, who are soliciting citizen ideas online at Rebuild the Party, said Matt Lerner, chief technology officer at Front Seat. He started getting involved in Democratic politics while working at Microsoft in 2004, when he founded Driving Votes to register Democratic voters in swing states.   "Appointing a C.T.O. has been an invitation for Silicon Valley to get more involved," said Mr. Lerner, who co-founded EQuill, a Web development software company, and sold it to Microsoft in 2001. "Hopefully the C.T.O., when elected, will take a look at the site and see what some of the priorities of the community will be."   Anyone can suggest priorities for the C.T.O. on the site, and users vote, Digg-style, for their favorites. The top idea right now, with 618 votes, is to open up government data like census stats and campaign finance data to programmers who want to build Web sites to analyze it. Others include equipping every community in the nation with broadband, building a nationwide smart grid and running the government on free, open-source software.   Mr. Lerner remembers a professor getting angry with him when he dropped out of graduate school to run a start-up. The professor lamented that when he was in school, all the best students went to Washington, but now they were going to Silicon Valley.   Mr. Lerner said he hopes the migration will change so that instead of building Facebook applications, engineers "will go to D.C. and try to make a difference."   Indeed, for the first time, techies are whispering about a brain drain from Silicon Valley to Washington. In the past, "they have felt that government is moving so slowly that it's not interesting to them," Mr. Lerner said. "But with the innovation around the Obama campaign and Obama appointing a C.T.O., technologists feel they really might have a role to play in helping the government become more innovative."   As for who the C.T.O. should be? Mr. Lerner said he doesn't have any ideas. Apple's chief executive Steve Jobs, is his technology hero, he said (yes, Mr. Lerner did spend six years working at Microsoft.) Yet people like Mr. Jobs would not be best for the position, he said, "because a lot of the great technologists are mavericks and innovators and might not function well in the more bureaucratic role."
abstract: A Seattle firm has created a new site, ObamaCTO.org, for people to funnel tech policy ideas to the Obama administration.

lead_paragraph: The main advice I got from people who blog — as well as from people who know people who blog — is that I should be careful, lest it take over my life. Blogging has a way of doing that — you’re always looking at the new comments coming in, and posting them (so long as they aren’t ad hominem attacks on someone, or contain foul language, etc. etc.) And you’re always thinking of subjects you can blog about. And then you feel guilty if you’re not. I wanted to say something about Hector Ruiz being replaced as chief executive of AMD — as much as I like Ruiz and admire his rags-to-riches story, it sure looks like AMD has returned to taking two steps back for every one step forward, just as it always has. (Hmm…I guess I just posted after all!) I continue to want to mock the anti-short-selling mania in Washington and on Wall Street. I thought it was only the Chinese whose government tried to prop up falling stock prices. I guess not.

snippet: Oracle has teamed with Hewlett-Packard, rather than traditional partners Sun and Dell, on new data warehousing hardware.
lead_paragraph: Oracle dealt a blow Wednesday to its longtime ally Sun Microsystems by "entering the hardware business" in tandem with Hewlett-Packard.   Oracle, best known for its database software and related applications, showed off a pair of new server systems that should make its database run faster than ever before and give the company a leg up in the growing field for systems known as data warehouses.   "That's right, Oracle is going into the hardware business. But we're not going alone," said Oracle's chief executive, Larry Ellison, speaking at the company's user conference in San Francisco.   Oracle, in fact, is not entering the hardware business in any traditional sense. Salespeople working for the software company can take orders for the new systems, but H.P. will make, deliver and service the gear –- just as it has always done.   The major difference with this partnership involves Oracle's decision to champion H.P. over its other close hardware partners like Sun and Dell. In the past, Oracle may very well have struck a deal like this with Sun, as Mr. Ellison has long counted Sun's chairman, Scott McNealy, as both a personal friend and strong business ally.   Times have changed, however with H.P.'s server business growing while Sun's declines. In addition, Sun acquired MySQL, a maker of open source database software that competes with Oracle.   As far as the hardware goes, Oracle will plant its database on an H.P. server that has vast amounts of storage. By placing lots of storage close to the processors inside the server, Oracle can bolster the performance of its database software, since requests for information no longer have to travel out to external storage systems over a network.  H.P. is then combining a number of these base systems with more of its regular servers to form something Oracle is calling a Database Machine.   "We are not talking the iPod Nano here," Mr. Ellison said. "This is 1,400 times larger than Apple's largest iPod. Even your peer-to-peer network will have a hard time filling this thing up."  Rather than having anything to do with music, the Database Machine is aimed at data warehousing jobs. This technology helps customers such as retailers and manufactures keep track of all their inventory, sales and other business data, and it lets them search and sort this data in sophisticated ways with the hopes of learning more about the state of a company's business.   A number of start-ups, along with Microsoft and I.B.M., also compete in the data warehouse market.   Wednesday's announcement appears to be more about branding than creating something new. The H.P. hardware being used by Oracle is very much standard gear. Any customer could assemble a Database Machine on its own.   And H.P. has its own line of data warehouse systems called NeoView. It's a natural play for H.P., since its chief executive, Mark Hurd, once captained Teradata, the leading data warehouse software maker, before taking over as the H.P. boss.   Mr. Ellison largely ignored the rest of Oracle's product line during his OpenWorld speech.   "It's weird for a software company to say hardware is the answer to the problem and not go into the software side at all," said China Martens, a software analyst at The 451 Group.

snippet: Green Gadgets: Downloadable widgets aimed at conserving energy.
lead_paragraph: Kate Galbraith and Azadeh Ensha have both recently visited the topic of energy and personal computers for The Times (here and here) — highlighting strategies that users can deploy to make computing a more energy-efficient affair.   Following up on those efforts, we now take a closer look at four third-party applications that can help take energy savings to the next level.   ***  (Photo: Google's widget lets you know how much energy you've saved. ) Google Energy Saver: While Apple and Yahoo refer to mini pop-up applications as widgets, Google calls its Google Energy Saver a gadget.   Whatever the nomenclature, the program requires the free Google Desktop search tool for Windows XP and Vista to use. Once installed, Google Energy Saver creates a power savings profile that adjusts a variety of power-sipping settings: lowering the WiFi adapter power, for instance, and decreasing the amount of time required to stop the hard disk from spinning.   I customized the profile to also keep the screen at full brightness while I'm working, but to fully dim it when I'm away from the computer.   Currently, the application tells me I've saved enough energy to "toast 188 slices of bread," since installing it last week. I'll no doubt think of that whenever I use my toaster oven.   *    Monitor Off: This Yahoo widget is a no-brainer for Mac and Windows users who can't be bothered tweaking energy settings, but still want to conserve.   Simply put, Monitor Off switches your computer's monitor to standby mode with a click of the mouse. It's especially suited for people who haven't made the leap to an LCD display because, as the widget's description points out, "A typical 17-inch CRT monitor consumes 80 watts electricity; putting it on standby reduces it to about 0-15 watts."   *  Deep Sleep: Unlike Windows, which offers both "Sleep" and "Hibernate" modes to save energy, Mac users have only one (easy) option to suspend their computers without turning them off: Sleep. Power users know that there is a way to turn on the Mac's own hibernate-like feature, but it involves typing Unix commands into the Terminal application.   An easier solution is Deep Sleep, a dashboard widget that knocks your Mac out cold just like Windows' hibernate. Unlike sleep, which continues to draw small amounts of power even though the computer appears to be off, hibernate draws no power. Instead, a file is created that remembers what you were doing and what programs you had open before the computer powered down. On rising from hibernation mode — which takes longer than emerging from sleep — that file permits you to take up where you left off.   *  (Photo: Verdiem's widget makes energy-efficient computing easy.) Edison: Windows users looking for a non-techie way to tweak their computer's energy settings will appreciate Verdiem's Edison.  Like Google's Energy Saver, Edison displays an estimate of how much energy you're saving from the settings you choose. Simple sliders let you choose to Save More, Save Less, or save somewhere in between. Options for activating energy settings during work- and non-work hours make it ideal for office computers, and the Schedule option allows weekend workers to adjust start and end timeframes as necessary.
abstract: Green Gadgets: Downloadable widgets aimed at conserving energy.

headline.main: Widgets Aimed at Conserving Energy
headline.print_headline: Saving Enough Computer Energy to "Toast 188 Slices of Bread"

snippet: The Fitbit Tracker, a gadget that will be available by January, uses a motion sensor to track users’ movement and sleep and give them a snapshot of their health.
lead_paragraph: Using the Fitbit Tracker is like having a personal trainer, nutritionist and sleep doctor attached to your hip at all times.   (Photo: ) The gadget, introduced Tuesday at the TechCrunch50 conference in San Francisco, tracks your health minute-to-minute -- measuring things like calories burned and quality of sleep -- and tells you whether you've exercised or slept too little.   An avatar, such as a flower, shrinks or grows based on how healthy you've been. Eat a cheeseburger for dinner, skip the gym and go to sleep late and your flower will wilt. Eat a salad, work out and get lots of sleep and it will bloom.   "Our primary motivation is to help everyday Americans to get up off the couch, exercise more, eat better and live a healthier life," said James Park, Fitbit's co-founder and chief executive.   Mr. Park came up with the idea after realizing he had become unhealthy. "I had been working like crazy at start-ups over the last three years and really let myself go in terms of fitness," he said. He is a walking advertisement for the gadget -- he has lost 15 pounds over the last 10 weeks while using it.   This is the third start-up that Mr. Park and his co-founder and chief technology officer, Eric Friedman, have created together. The first failed during the dot-com bust. They sold the second, photo-sharing service Windup Labs, to CNet in 2005.   The Fitbit Tracker is a small, wireless device, the size of a thumb. It uses a motion sensor called an accelerometer, similar to that found in the Nintendo Wii, to track movement. A wireless base station collects information every time the user walks by and uploads it to a Web site, fitbit.com.   It comes in white or black and looks a bit like an Apple device, sleek and uncluttered. Users clip it to their clothing, hold it in their pockets or, as female testers have done, clip it to their bras. It tracks exercise, calories burned, steps taken, distance moved and sleep length and quality.   On the Web site, users can enter the food they have consumed to get a fuller picture of health and calorie count. Mr. Park acknowledged that entering meals and snacks can be tedious, but he said that people who are serious about losing weight seem motivated to do it. Fitbit.com includes a database of common foods and shortcuts like favorite foods and meals to simplify the process.   Users can click a button on the Fitbit Tracker to get an update on calories and exercise or check on the health of their avatar. On the Web site, a box displays their weight, body mass index, calories burned and steps walked. A graph depicts a breakdown of daily activity and levels of intensity at different times of day. Another graph shows how long it took them to fall asleep, how long they slept and how many times they woke up. A chart depicts how close they are to their pre-set goals and how many more calories they can consume or need to burn to get there. A social networking component lets users form groups with friends to compete with one another or cheer one another on.   The gadget will be available for pre-order in September and will ship early next year. It costs $99 and the Web site is free to use. Mr. Park plans to add a premium subscription feature in the future, which would charge users for personalized nutrition and fitness plans and coaching.
abstract: The Fitbit Tracker, a gadget that will be available by January, uses a motion sensor to track users’ movement and sleep and give them a snapshot of their health.

headline.main: Fitness Gadget Aims to Help Users Lose Weight
headline.print_headline: Fitness Gadget Aims to Help Users Lose Weight

snippet: Wholesale prices for the L.C.D. panels have been dropping and excess inventory is forcing HDTV prices down as companies try to get rid of their finished products so they can move in new models.
lead_paragraph: In his now-famous letter to early buyers of last year’s first generation iPhone, Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, told customers who were angry that its price was lowered by $200 just a few months after launch, that price drops in technology were a given. “This is life in the technology lane,” he said in an open letter to consumers. “If you always wait for the next price cut or to buy the new improved model, you’ll never buy any technology product because there is always something better and less expensive on the horizon.”

snippet: The neighborhood Barrio de las Letras has been hit by a wave of stylish interior designers.
lead_paragraph: THE Spanish adjective castizo describes something that is quintessentially Castilian and, as far as neighborhoods in Madrid go, few are more castizo than the Barrio de las Letras. Climbing the hill opposite the Prado museum, this district of narrow lanes, brick houses and elaborate ironwork balconies was named after Spain’s men of letters, literary lions from the 17th century like Miguel de Cervantes and Lope de Vega.

lead_paragraph: Health work in poor countries looks easy — vaccinate the kids, treat malaria, prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS — and yet in fact it’s extraordinarily difficult and has often failed. Because of AIDS, life expectancy has fallen. A quarter more women die in childbirth now in Africa than in 1990. As for malaria, we don’t even have a good sense of the scale of the challenge. We roll out multi-billion dollar anti-retroviral programs for AIDS, but we don’t even deworm kids or iodize salt — two simple interventions that would raise school attendance, reduce malnutrition and anemia, and prevent cognitive impairment and even cretinism.
abstract: Health work in poor countries looks easy — vaccinate the kids, treat malaria, prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS — and yet in fact it’s extraordinarily difficult and has often failed. Because of AIDS, life expectancy has fallen. A quarter more women die in childbirth now in Africa than in 1990. As for malaria, we don’t even have a good sense of the scale of the challenge. We roll out multi-billion dollar anti-retroviral programs for AIDS, but we don’t even deworm kids or iodize salt — two simple interventions that would raise school attendance, reduce malnutrition and anemia, and prevent cognitive impairment and even cretinism.

headline.main: Are Doctors Screwing Up Public Health?

snippet: “The Duchess” is an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.
lead_paragraph: No bodices rip in “The Duchess,” an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl, but Ralph Fiennes does take scissors to Keira Knightley’s unmentionables for some shivery snip-snip. Based on a true story, as they say in the movies, the tale traces the cosseted, tightly corseted late-18th-century life of Georgiana Spencer, the Duchess of Devonshire, one of those gilded-cage aristocrats who appear to have been primed, pumped and exclusively prized for the fecundity of their wombs. If the name of another suffering Spencer (guess!) popped into your head, you have made the filmmakers very happy.
abstract: “The Duchess” is an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.

headline.main: Georgiana and Her Dull, Dallying Duke

snippet: I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry.
lead_paragraph: AT high noon on a recent Monday, I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry. Just 72 hours earlier, I had taken delivery on a Dell Inspiron 1720 laptop loaded with Microsoft Windows Vista. It was already on the blink. I couldn’t open a Word document. I couldn’t run a Google search. I couldn’t even send e-mail. I vowed to shave Michael Dell and Bill Gates with a broken beer bottle.
abstract: I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry.

headline.main: Sending an S O S for a PC Exorcist

snippet: The human mind as a mess of parts, arbitrarily yet effectively assembled.
lead_paragraph: In April 1970, the astronauts on the Apollo 13 space mission faced a life-threatening crisis. Levels of carbon dioxide inside their craft were climbing dangerously, and there were no filters to replace the ones that were failing. Working quickly, the crew members assembled a makeshift filter out of materials on board  including a sock, a plastic bag and some duct tape  allowing them to return safely to Earth.
abstract: The human mind as a mess of parts, arbitrarily yet effectively assembled.

snippet: “ ‘Home to stay, Glory! Yes!’ her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration.”
lead_paragraph: "Home to stay, Glory! Yes!" her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration. "To stay for a while this time!" he amended, and took her bag from her, first shifting his cane to his weaker hand. Dear God, she thought, dear God in heaven. So began and ended all her prayers these days, which were really cries of amazement. How could her father be so frail? And how could he be so recklessly intent on satisfying his notions of gentlemanliness, hanging his cane on the railing of the stairs so he could, dear God, carry her bag up to her room? But he did it, and then he stood by the door, collecting himself.
abstract: “ ‘Home to stay, Glory! Yes!’ her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration.”

headline.main: ‘Home’

snippet: It’s not just for cream puffs anymore.
lead_paragraph: I fell for choux paste, a k a cream-puff dough, early in my cooking career. At one of my first restaurant jobs, creating pretty slices for our cheese-plate service left the kitchen with countless dismal little ends of cheese. (We cooks called them cheese butts.) Choux (pronounced SHOO) paste proved the perfect home for the orphaned bits of Boucheron, Roquefort and cheddar. The cheeses would be stirred into the paste, which then was shaped into neat quenelles and fried into beignets; crisp on the exterior, oozy and fragrant on the interior. From near garbage came near perfection, all thanks to a strange, decidedly old-fashioned dough.
abstract: It’s not just for cream puffs anymore.

snippet: For an urban second-home buyer, the allure of a farmhouse in the northern Catskills has much to do with the setting.
lead_paragraph: FOR an urban second-home buyer, the allure of a farmhouse in the northern Catskills has much to do with the setting. There, rolling pastures are bordered by blue-green mountains that rise from the edges of patchwork farmland; languid cows graze in meadows bordered by stone walls; and stands of sugar maples line winding roads where silos and red barns are commonplace. There are log homes, chalets and manufactured homes, too, but in Delaware County, it is the indigenous farmhouse that defines the regional aesthetic.
abstract: For an urban second-home buyer, the allure of a farmhouse in the northern Catskills has much to do with the setting.

snippet: “ ‘Home to stay, Glory! Yes!’ her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration.”
lead_paragraph: "Home to stay, Glory! Yes!" her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration. "To stay for a while this time!" he amended, and took her bag from her, first shifting his cane to his weaker hand. Dear God, she thought, dear God in heaven. So began and ended all her prayers these days, which were really cries of amazement. How could her father be so frail? And how could he be so recklessly intent on satisfying his notions of gentlemanliness, hanging his cane on the railing of the stairs so he could, dear God, carry her bag up to her room? But he did it, and then he stood by the door, collecting himself.
abstract: “ ‘Home to stay, Glory! Yes!’ her father said, and her heart sank. He attempted a twinkle of joy at this thought, but his eyes were damp with commiseration.”

headline.main: ‘Home’

lead_paragraph: IT is in Midtown that Atlanta feels most like a real city. That is where the sprawl finally ends, where Costco and Outback give way to condos and Outwrite (the gay bookshop). There is a vertical grace to the streetscape, a fundamental yet all too rare appreciation for proportion and design. Home to the arts center, a great urban park and some of Atlanta’s best restaurants, the district has a vitality that is at once hip and sophisticated.

lead_paragraph: It's not every day that a respected rap producer and a speaker-wire company team up to make a pair of headphones. Beats by Dr. Dre Headphones, manufactured by Monster Cable in collaboration with Dr. Dre, are noise-reducing headphones tuned to the demands of rock and hip-hop. Beats, like similar models from Bose and Sennheiser, reduce ambient noise and create a seal over the ears to ensure audio clarity. The headphones can also be used as an iPhone headset, with the included microphone attachment, and they fit almost any MP3 player or music-playing mobile phone.

snippet: Eva Chen is the chief executive of Trend Micro, an antivirus software firm.
lead_paragraph: I LIVED in Taipei until I was 22. I graduated as a philosophy major. My grandfather was a politician and then founded a bank. My father was a philosophy major and then inherited the banking business. I think philosophy is a base that trains you how to think.

lead_paragraph: For most of its history, the Sagrantino grape grew solely in Italy, in the Umbrian town of Montefalco. It made a sweet wine used for sacramental purposes. In the 1980s a dry style emerged. I adore its sandpaper-like tannins, sun-baked fruit and rusty iron acidity. Two favorites of mine are Filippo Antonelli, whose wine is shy and elegant, and Paolo Bea, which is chestnut, honeyed and seductive. So when my friend Kevin Hamel raised the possibility of making wine with Sagrantino grapes in California with Ridgely Evers of DaVero, the olive oil and wine producer in the Dry Creek Valley in Sonoma County, I was interested.

snippet: The thrust of the throat was the last thing I expected to see on a men’s runway. The male torso may have been a focus of attention since Adonis and the Olympics, when Greeks, rather than geeks, ruled the world. But those bodies were about rippling...
lead_paragraph: The thrust of the throat was the last thing I expected to see on a men’s runway. The male torso may have been a focus of attention since Adonis and the Olympics, when Greeks, rather than geeks, ruled the world. But those bodies were about rippling muscles, heaving pectorals and sporty might. At Prada’s spring 2009 show, I was apparently viewing sweet and gentle exposure, with blouson jackets hanging from lean straps on bared shoulders and scoop-neck sweaters that fixed my eyes on the Adam’s apple. Then I looked down at the feet. Normal shoes  except for a fetish strap across the instep. By the time the shows closed, I’d seen more clavicles and weirdo shoes (toe spats at Vuitton, winged flaps at Raf Simons) and fewer ties than in living memory. Finally it dawned on me: I’d witnessed the search for a new male erogenous zone.
abstract: The thrust of the throat was the last thing I expected to see on a men’s runway. The male torso may have been a focus of attention since Adonis and the Olympics, when Greeks, rather than geeks, ruled the world. At Prada’s spring 2009 show, I was apparently viewing sweet and gentle exposure, with blouson jackets hanging from lean straps on bared shoulders and scoop-neck sweaters that fixed my eyes on the Adam’s apple. Then I looked down at the feet. Normal shoes — except for a fetish strap across the instep. By the time the shows closed, I’d seen more clavicles and weirdo shoes (toe spats at Vuitton, winged flaps at Raf Simons) and fewer ties than in living memory. Finally it dawned on me: I’d witnessed the search for a new male erogenous zone.

lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Ontario — Though a consumer may not be able to tell the difference, a striking red and blue Thomas the Tank Engine made in Wisconsin is not the same as one manufactured in China - the paint on the Chinese twin may contain dangerous levels of lead. The imported fruits and vegetables found in our shopping carts in winter and early spring are grown with types and amounts of pesticides that would often be illegal in the United States.

lead_paragraph: The latest tome by J.K. Rowling has started to fly off bookstore shelves. Rowling launched "The Tales of Beedle the Bard" with a tea party for 200 schoolchildren at the National Library of Scotland in Edinburgh, where she lives. The author is donating royalties from the book to a charity for vulnerable children. Booksellers hope the book, a collection of five fables mentioned in Rowling's saga about boy wizard Harry Potter, will give them a festive boost. Jon Howells of Britain's Waterstone's bookstore chain said it had "a fighting chance of being the best-selling book of the year, even though there are only a few weeks to go." Such is the magic of Rowling. "Beedle the Bard" is being published in more than 20 countries, with a global print run of almost eight million. (AP)

snippet: There is little danger of being labeled effete in the home of Oktoberfest and oom-pah bands.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When one thinks of beer and bratwurst, one tends to think of either faraway Germany -- or Milwaukee in the heartland.   That quirk of culinary geography says a lot about why Barack Obama can give a public speech in Berlin without catching the kind of flak that a similar outing under the Eiffel Tower would garner.  As the Obama campaign searched for a location here for his public address before a crowd that is expected to reach at least into the tens of thousands, a great deal of attention was paid to the backdrop within the city. Little was paid to the choice of country itself.  Yet Germany is an easy call for a number of reasons. It is the site of two of America's most cherished victories, over the Nazi regime in World War II and the Soviets in the Cold War. And for the Obama campaign, comparisons to President Kennedy are always welcome as long as they do not appear too overtly sought after. Do not expect to hear Mr. Obama claim, auf deutsch, that he is a Berliner.  But a broader combination of social, historical and even demographic factors make Germany a hit for American politicians going abroad, whether it be Mr. Obama or President Bush, who in 2006 enjoyed a hearty meal of barbecued pig on a spit with Chancellor Angela Merkel.   Campaigning abroad means delving into American perceptions and stereotypes about foreign countries, even among allies. No political operative could forget the way French became pejorative shorthand for elitism against John Kerry in the 2004 campaign.  One might think that the French would have a leg up in the public-relations game, thanks to Lafayette and de Tocqueville. Yet an appearance in Germany brings few of the dangers that a campaign speech before cheering throngs in the land of pinot and foie gras might. While plenty could go wrong, and a backlash is still possible, one thing is clear: There is little danger of being labeled effete in the home of Oktoberfest and oom-pah bands.   Germany can be, well, pretty American sometimes. And often overlooked is just how German the United States really is.   As the American ambassador noted when opening the new embassy to Germany on the Fourth of July, in the 2000 census the number of Americans reporting German ancestry was nearly 43 million, the highest tally of any group. That's more than Irish or English or Italian, some five times the number claiming French roots and roughly the same number as African-American and Mexican combined.  The same debates that take place today over Latino immigrants and the Spanish language once centered around the German communities, which had their own newspapers, schools and theaters. At the peak of German migration to the United States 1.8 million came between 1880 and 1893, according to Klaus Bade, a professor at the University of Osnabrück and founder of the Institute for Migration Research and Intercultural Studies.   To put that in perspective, that came at a time when the population of the United States was only around 50 million, or one-sixth of what it is today. That enormous influx left a lasting influence on American culture. It was -- and still is -- particularly powerful in the heartland. The Census Bureau said that every state in the Midwest reports Germany as the largest share of ancestry, with 44 percent in North Dakota and 43 percent in Wisconsin.  The identification with German ancestry in America receded in the 20th century for a couple of reasons. First, according to Professor Bade, the wave of immigrants came to an unusually abrupt halt as Germany went from having too few jobs to too many.   The other reason is a little more obvious: Germany's place as America's enemy in two consecutive world wars.  Yet the significant American role in rebuilding and defending West Germany after the war led to what in some ways amounted to the largest exchange program in history, even if the leading edge was soldiers instead of students. That meant new contacts and even more chances for cross-pollination.  "There are an enormous number of organic connections between Germans and Americans," said Jackson Janes, executive director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies in Washington, an independent think tank. He said that between 14 million and 16 million Americans were stationed in Germany since the 1940s, especially military families and their dependents.   The transformation of Germany from violent dictatorship to peaceful democracy stands as one of the great accomplishments in American history, a significant point of pride for the country. That may be why, even at the nadir of relations, Germany never caught the same degree of criticism as France for opposing the Iraq invasion. Though former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was against the war in Iraq, it was cheese-eating surrender monkeys, not schnitzel-eating surrender monkeys.   Senator Obama may not say, "Ich bin ein Berliner," this summer, but he need have no fear diving into a few frankfurters or hamburgers at an American picnic. The meat and potato Germans, their cuisine, and a lot of their culture, is as American as apple struedel, er, pie.
abstract: There is little danger of being labeled effete in the home of Oktoberfest and oom-pah bands.

headline.main: As German as ... America
headline.print_headline: As German as … America

lead_paragraph: A year from now, the presidency of George W. Bush will end, but the consequences of Bush's policies and the arguments about them are likely to be with us for a long time. As next Jan. 20 draws near, there is an evident temptation, among many journalists as well as politicians seeking to replace Bush, to close the book and move ahead, an impulse that makes the existence of documentaries like Alex Gibney's "Taxi to the Dark Side" all the more vital. If recent American history is ever going to be discussed with the necessary clarity and ethical rigor, this film will be essential.

The City Council grudgingly added to that time-honored clash on Wednesday, approving a bill that will increase the number of fruit and vegetable carts in the city’s poor neighborhoods.

headline.main: Council Vote for Good Health May Weaken Business at Groceries in Poor Neighborhoods

lead_paragraph: There has been much debate in the U.S. presidential campaign about which of America's enemies the next president should deign to talk to. The real story, the next president may discover, though, is how few countries are waiting around for America to call. It is hard to remember a time when more shifts in the global balance of power are happening at once - with so few in America's favor.

lead_paragraph: Sprint Nextel has generated a lot of deal buzz this week. The wireless carrier just signed an agreement with Clearwire and a consortium of other companies to build a high-speed wireless Internet service. The deal came as two rumors were making the rounds: that Sprint might spin off or sell its beleaguered Nextel unit, or be bought by Deutsche Telekom, which operates the rival mobile service T-Mobile USA.

snippet: There is a cookie-cutter sameness to many steakhouses, but Mac’s, in Huntington, breaks the mold.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a cookie-cutter sameness to many steakhouses, but Mac’s, in Huntington, breaks the mold. All its beef is from Niman Ranch, grass fed and dry aged at least 28 days. The pork is from the Berkshire breed. The restaurant also serves a few dishes rarely seen on Long Island, like braised beef cheeks and Hawaiian white tuna.
abstract: There is a cookie-cutter sameness to many steakhouses, but Mac’s, in Huntington, breaks the mold.

headline.main: In a Lustrous Space, Steak Plus Dishes Rarely Seen

snippet: Joe Burk was a single sculls champion of the 1930s who became a leading figure in American rowing and a highly decorated PT boat skipper in World War II.
lead_paragraph: Joe Burk, a single sculls champion of the 1930s who became a leading figure in American rowing and a highly decorated PT boat skipper in World War II, died Jan. 13 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 93.

lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning last June, the wind was howling across a craggy stretch of France's Côte Sauvage, or Wild Coast, on the tiny peninsula off Brittany called Quiberon. Standing in the wind, arms outstretched, my traveling companions and I had the sense we might blow out to sea, or at least back toward the pretty houses that line the seaside town of Quiberon.

lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Perhaps more than any other European city, Vienna has a lasting reverence for its culinary traditions, with white-tablecloth destinations like Hotel Sacher, Demel and Drei Husaren occupying the center stage for what seems like most of the past few centuries. But recently, a new generation has started to challenge that old order, updating the Austrian capital's traditionally formal dining scene with casual restaurants in unexpected settings, from inside museums to cheese shops and even bookstores.
abstract: VIENNA — Perhaps more than any other European city, Vienna has a lasting reverence for its culinary traditions, with white-tablecloth destinations like Hotel Sacher, Demel and Drei Husaren occupying the center stage for what seems like most of the past few centuries. snippet: A new book, “Branding New York: How a City in Crisis Was Sold to the World,” argues that a coalition of elites came together in the 1970s to brand a new image for their embattled city.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office in 2002, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has named a chief marketing officer; pushed to attract huge events like the Republican National Convention; urged the construction of new sports stadiums in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and the West Side of Manhattan (with varying degrees of success); and tried to market the city under a new slogan, “The World’s Second Home.”
abstract: A new book, “Branding New York: How a City in Crisis Was Sold to the World,” argues that a coalition of elites came together in the 1970s to brand a new image for their embattled city.

headline.main: When New York Branded Its Way Out of Crisis
